title: Taylor, Cotton & Ridley v. Okatie Hotel Group
description: In reviewing this action enforcing Taylor, Cotton, & Ridley's (Subcontractor) mechanic's lien, the S.C. Court of Appeals affirmed the trial court's findings that neither the mechanic's lien statutes nor after discovered negligence reduced Okatie Hotel Group's (Owner) liability to Subcontractor.    The Court of Appels reversed the trial court on the assignment of interest and remanded for a determination of a pre-judgment interest rate consistent with Section 34-31-20 of the South carolina Code.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Taylor, Cotton & Ridley, Inc., Respondent,
v.
Okatie Hotel Group, LLC; The Devcon Group, Inc., SunTrust Bank, Savannah, N. A.; Capitol Materials of Savannah, Inc., Pro Slab, Inc. f/k/a
OPP, Incorporated; Genco of Simpsonville, Inc., Imperial Marble Corporation; Turner Electrical of South Carolina, Inc., Cassidy of South Carolina, Inc., Cassidy Oâ€™Sullivan & Co.; Best Plumbing, Inc. and Malphrus Construction Company, Inc., Defendants, 
Of whom Okatie Hotel Group, LLC is the Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Beaufort County
Â Thomas Kemmerlin, Special Referee

Opinion No. 4194
Heard November 7, 2006 â€“ Filed January 8, 2007           

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART
AND REMANDED.


  
    
      
W. Duvall Spruill, of Columbia, for Appellant.
John S. Nichols, of Columbia; Marvin H. Dukes, of Beaufort, for Respondent.
      
    
  

SHORT, J.:Â  Okatie Hotel Group, LLC (Owner) appeals the trial courtâ€™s failure to consider settlement payments to seven other subcontractors (Other Subcontractors) and damages to the building when determining Ownerâ€™s liability to Taylor, Cotton and Ridley, Inc. (Subcontractor).Â  Owner also appeals the trial courtâ€™s disregard of a waiver made by Subcontractor, use of an interest rate greater than the statutory maximum, and award of attorneysâ€™ fees.Â  We affirm in part, reverse in part, and remand.
FACTS
The Devcon Group, Inc. (General Contractor) served as the general contractor for Ownerâ€™s development of the Marriott Fairfield Inn.Â  General Contractor hired Subcontractor to install door frames and locks for the development at an original contract price of $91,570.00. This original contract price increased to $115,085.75, due to additional line items, a revised door frame jam, and installation of â€œVing cardâ€ locks.Â  Subcontractor finished all major work and billed General Contractor by November 23, 1999, but was called back to the job site on several occasions to perform further installations and repairs.Â  By December 6, 1999, Subcontractor had submitted a notice of non-payment and received $20,000 toward the total contract price of $115,085.75.Â  The last service performed by Subcontractor was on March 8, 2000, when Subcontractor returned to install and repair exterior door locks. On April 24, 2000, Subcontractor filed a mechanicâ€™s lien for the $95,085.75 which remained due under the contract.Â  
The amended total contract between General Contractor and Owner was $2,421,656.00, and prior to Subcontractorâ€™s lien filing, Owner paid General Contractor $2,166,613.00. Other Subcontractors claimed liens totaling $146,330.00, but, following mediation in the spring of 2001, they settled for $92,385.00.Â  All Other Subcontractors participated in this mediation, but Subcontractor did not.Â  
Subcontractor filed suit against General Contractor and Owner to enforce Subcontractorâ€™s lien against the developed property.Â  At trial, the court adjusted the contract price by first decreasing it to $2,417,564.00 to reflect back charges, and then by increasing it to $2,461,510.00 to include change orders.Â  The trial court found no adjustments were necessary for liquidated damages and held General Contractor and Owner were jointly and severally liable to Subcontractor for the lien of $95,085.15 with a 1.5% interest rate beginning in December of 1999.Â  This accrued interest brought the total judgment amount to $184,940.62.Â  In addition to this amount, the court, through a subsequent order issued on September 22, 2005, awarded Subcontractor $31,272.19 in attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œA proceeding for the enforcement of a statutory lien, such as a mechanicâ€™s lien, is legal in nature.â€ Butler Contracting, Inc. v. Court Street, LLC, 369 S.C. 121, ___, 631 S.E.2d 252, 255 (2006) (citing Willard v. Finch, 123 S.C. 56, 116 S.E.2d 96 (1923)). Â In an action at law tried without a jury, the trial courtâ€™s findings of fact will be upheld on appeal when the findings are reasonably supported by the evidence. Â Butler Contracting, 369 S.C. at ___, 631 S.E.2d at 255.Â  The trial courtâ€™s findings of fact will not be disturbed on appeal unless wholly unsupported by the evidence or
clearly influenced or controlled by an error of law. Â Id. at ___, 631 S.E.2d at 255-56. 
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.  Credit for Payments to Other Subcontractors 
Owner argues that sections 29-5-20, 29-5-40, and 29-5-60 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005) require the trial court to credit Owner for the settlement reached with Other Subcontractors before determining the amount owed Subcontractor.Â  Owner paid Other Subcontractors 66.6% of their claimed lien amounts and sought to limit any amount paid to Subcontractor to this same percentage.Â  At the time Owner settled with Other Subcontractors through mediation, Owner was aware of Subcontractorâ€™s outstanding lien. The trial court held that Subcontractor was not bound by the prorated limit in the settlement between Owner and Other Subcontractors.Â  We agree.
Section 29-5-20(a) states:

Every laborer, mechanic, subcontractor, or person furnishing material for the improvement of real estate when the improvement has been authorized by the owner has a lien thereon, subject to existing liens of which he has actual or constructive notice, to the value of the labor or material so furnished, including the costs of the action and a reasonable attorneyâ€™s fee which must be determined by the court in which the action is brought but only if the party seeking to enforce the lien prevails. If the party defending against the lien prevails, the defending party must be awarded costs of the action and a reasonable attorneyâ€™s fee as determined by the court. The fee and the court costs may not exceed the amount of the lien. The lien may be enforced as
herein provided.

Additionally section 29-5-40 states:

Whenever work is done or material is furnished for the improvement of real estate upon the employment of a contractor or some other person than the owner and such laborer, mechanic, contractor or materialman shall in writing notify the owner of the furnishing of such labor or material and the amount or value thereof, the lien given by Â§29-5-20 shall attach upon the real estate improved as against the true owner for the amount of the work done or material furnished. But in no event shall the aggregate amount of liens set up hereby exceed the amount due by the owner on the contract price of the improvement made.

(emphasis added).
The main purposes of sections 29-5-20 and 29-5-40 are (1) the protection through a lien of a party, who furnished labor or material but was not a party to a contract with the owner and (2) the protection of the owner by preventing his liability on the liens from exceeding the amount owner owes on the contract price.Â  Lowndes Hill Realty Co. v. Greenville Concrete Co., 229 S.C. 619, 629, 93 S.E.2d 855, 860 (1956).[1]Â  Subcontractor brought this action in order to enforce his lien after providing labor to Owner.Â  
The trial court adjusted the contract price to $2,461,510.00 based on change orders and back charges.Â  Owner paid General Contractor $2,166,613.00, and Owner settled with Other Subcontractors for $92,385.00, which leaves a difference of $202,512.00 between the contract price and the amount paid by Owner.Â  Subcontractorâ€™s lien is for $95,085.75.Â  Therefore, section 29-5-40 is not violated because the difference between the contract price and amount Owner already paid is greater than Subcontractorâ€™s lien amount.Â  
Section 29-5-60(a) (Supp. 2005) imposes a duty on Owner to settle and states:Â  â€œIn the event the amount due the contractor by the owner is insufficient to pay all the lienors acquiring liens as herein provided it is the duty of the owner to prorate among all just claims the amount due the contractor.â€Â  When a lien attaches the subcontractor has a â€œjust claim.â€ Charleston Lumber Co., Inc. v. GPT, 303 S.C. 350, 353, 400 S.E.2d 508, 510 (Ct. App. 1991).Â  Â Subcontractor attached a lien for $95,085.75, which gave subcontractor a just claim.Â  
Subcontractorâ€™s just claim creates a duty on Owner under section 29-5-60.Â  â€œThe cardinal rule of statutory construction is that words used in a statute should be given their plain and ordinary meaning unless something in the statute requires a different interpretation.â€Â  Seckinger v. Vessel Excalibur, 326 S.C. 382, 387, 483 S.E.2d 775, 777 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  A plain reading of section 29-5-60 requires an owner to prorate just claims when they exceed the amount due under the contract, but does not create a duty for the subcontractor to accept the prorated settlement.
The Mechanicâ€™s Lien statute (Section 29-5-60) does not credit owners who settle claims of non-perfected lien holders. Charleston Lumber, 303 S.C. at 353, 400 S.E.2d at 510.Â  In the same regard, the Mechanicâ€™s Lien statute does not contain a provision requiring Subcontractor to settle or be forced to receive a prorated judgment as long as the aggregate amount of the liens do not exceed the amount due by the owner on the contract price.Â  See Â§Â§ 29-5-20, 29-5-40, and 29-5-60.Â  Therefore, a trial court need only consider whether a prior settlement agreement decreases the ownerâ€™s contract liability to an amount smaller than the litigated lien. In this case, the settlement with Other Subcontractors did not decrease the remaining liability to a sum smaller than Subcontractorâ€™s lien.Â  Accordingly, the trial court properly determined that Subcontractorâ€™s lien was enforceable and did not violate South Carolina law.
II.  Consideration of Property Damages 
Owner argues the trial court should have considered damage to the developed building when it determined the adjusted contract price which was used to calculate Ownerâ€™s remaining liability to the General Contractor and, ultimately, to Subcontractor.[2]Â  We disagree.Â  
In a claim to enforce a mechanicâ€™s lien, the trial courtâ€™s findings are not to be disturbed unless the findings are wholly unsupported by evidence. Butler Contracting, 369 S.C. at ___, 631 S.E.2d at 255-56.Â  In this case, the trial court adjusted the contract price based on back charges and change orders.Â  The damages Owner feels the trial court should have considered concern the alleged improper installation of insulation resulting in $651,551.00 in mold damage to the building.Â  Owner sought to have this amount deducted from the adjusted contract price prior to determining its liability to Subcontractor.Â  The trial court excluded evidence regarding mold damage as inapplicable to this litigation holding â€œafter discovered negligence may not be asserted by way of off-set because it has not pled.â€Â  Because the damage was not discovered until after Ownerâ€™s pleading was submitted, the pleading obviously did not contain any reference to the damage.Â  Moreover, evidence exists in the record that General Contractor may not have caused the mold problem.Â  Ownerâ€™s own witness testified that he inspected the insulation after its installation and found no problems, and he further testified that he had no evidence that General Contractor was responsible for the faulty insulation.Â  The evidence in the record supports the trial courtâ€™s finding that mold damage was inapplicable to this matter.Â  Therefore, the trial courtâ€™s ruling on liquidated damages is affirmed.
III.  Waiver 
Owner argues the trial court did not pay sufficient deference to Subcontractorâ€™s pay applications, which included a waiver and release of lien clause.Â  We disagree.
â€œWhen a contract is unambiguous a court must construe its provisions according to the terms the parties used, understood in their plain, ordinary, and popular sense.â€Â  S.C. Farm Bureau Mutual Ins. Co. v. Oates, 356 S.C. 378, 381, 588 S.E.2d 643, 645 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  In this case, the waiver section of the payment application is titled â€œWAIVER AND RELEASE OF LIEN UPON PROGRESS PAYMENT,â€ and the waiver states Subcontractor agrees to waive and release its lien â€œin consideration of the progress payment.â€Â  The trial court found the waiver language in the payment application conditioned the waiver upon payment taking place.Â  It is undisputed that Subcontractor was not paid upon completion of the job.Â  Therefore, the trial courtâ€™s finding that Subcontractorâ€™s payment application included merely a conditioned waiver â€œto be held in trust pending paymentâ€ was supported by the evidence and shall not be disturbed. See Butler Contracting, 369 S.C. at __, 631 S.E.2d at 255-56.
IV.  Interest Rate 
Owner disputes the interest rate the trial court ordered Owner to pay Subcontractor because the interest rate exceeds the statutory limit, and Owner
and Subcontractor did not contract for a higher interest rate.Â  We agree. 
Section 34-31-20 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005) sets an interest rate for all cases in which money is found to be due.Â  The established pre-judgment legal interest rate for ascertainable sums of money is 8.75% per annum.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 34-31-20(A) (Supp. 2005).Â  The ascertained liquidated damages in this matter are $95,085.75.Â Â  Despite the existence of section 34-31-20, parties are free to agree to higher interest rates within legal limits.Â 
Butler Contracting, 369 S.C. at __, 631 S.E.2d at 259.Â  The trial court ordered Owner to pay Subcontractor 1.5% per month (18% per annum) prejudgment interest beginning in December 1999, which exceeds the 8.75% statutory annual interest rate. Evidence exists in the record that General Contractor and Subcontractor contractually agreed to a higher interest rate of 1.5% per month.Â  However, Subcontractor and Owner did not contract for a higher interest rate.Â  Therefore, we find Owner is not bound by General Contractorâ€™s agreement with Subcontractor.Â  Accordingly, we remand for a determination of a pre-judgment interest rate consistent with section 34-31-20.[3]
V.  Attorneysâ€™ Fees 
Owner contends that if this Court reverses some portion of the trial courtâ€™s order, then Subcontractor would not be the prevailing party and would not be entitled to attorneysâ€™ fees.Â  We disagree.
Section 29-5-20 (A) of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005) provides attorneysâ€™ fees for the prevailing party in an action to enforce a lien.Â 
In an action to enforce a mechanicâ€™s lien, the prevailing party receives a favorable decision or verdict on liability. Seckinger, 326 S.C. at 388, 483 S.E.2d at 778. The award of attorneysâ€™ fees is left undisturbed absent abuse of the trial courtâ€™s discretion.Â  Patrick v. Britt, 364 S.C. 508, 514, 613 S.E.2d 541, 544 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  Despite the remand for determination of an interest rate consistent with section 34-31-20, Subcontractor received a favorable verdict regarding liability.Â  Therefore, as the prevailing party, Subcontractor may be properly awarded attorneysâ€™ fees.
CONCLUSION
This court finds the trial court did not err in: 1) refusing to credit Owner for payments made to Other Subcontractors, 2) refusing to consider after discovered property damage in determining the adjusted contract price, 3) finding the waiver clause in the payment application was an unsatisfied conditional waiver, and 4) awarding attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  We find the trial court erred in its determination of a pre-judgment interest rate.Â  For the reasons stated herein, the trial courtâ€™s decision is 
AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED.
GOOLSBY, J., and STILWELL, J., concur.

[1] This cited case refers to sections 45-252 and 45-254 of the South Carolina Code.Â  These sections have since become sections 29-5-20 and 29-5-40, respectively.Â  
[2] As per Â§ 29-5-40, Subcontractor could not claim a lien for an amount
in excess of the amount still owed toÂ  the General Contractor under the contract.
[3] Subcontractor disputes the preservation of Ownerâ€™s issue regarding the higher interest rate.Â  In Ownerâ€™s brief to the trial court, Owner disputes the use of 1.5% per month interest rate based on an agreement between General Contractor and Subcontractor.Â  The trial courtâ€™s order sets the interest rate as 1.5% per month.Â  Therefore the issue was preserved because it was raised before and ruled upon by the trial court. See Holy Loch Distrib., Inc. v. Hitchcock, 340 S.C. 20, 24, 531 S.E.2d 282, 284 (2000).

description: David Rhoad appeals his two contempt convictions and two, consecutive sentences to six months.  He argues: (1) the PCR court erred in finding him in contempt; and (2) the sentences should be vacated because he was entitled to a jury trial.  We affirm.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        David Rhoad, Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        The State, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Aiken County
Â Doyet A. Early, III, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4195
Submitted November 1, 2006 â€“ Filed January 16, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Dudek, of Columbia; for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant Attorney General Deborah R.J. Shupe, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Barbara R. Morgan, of Aiken, for Respondent.
      
    
  

BEATTY, J.:Â  David Rhoad appeals the post-conviction relief (PCR) judgeâ€™s decision to hold him in contempt.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
Rhoad was convicted of DUI and criminal domestic violence of a high and aggravated nature (CDVHAN) and sentenced to five years imprisonment.Â  Rhoad filed a PCR application, but he informed the PCR judge on the day of the hearing that he wished to withdraw his application.Â  After the judge accepted his withdrawal, Rhoad made an obscene gesture to his trial counsel before leaving the courtroom.Â  
Rhoad was brought back into the courtroom and questioned about his actions.Â  Rhoad first admitted he â€œmight have flipped [trial counsel] off,â€ but then he denied that he did it.Â  The judge took testimony from witnesses in the courtroom to confirm that Rhoad had in fact made an obscene gesture.Â  Rhoad then informed the judge of his frustration with his trial counsel, and he apologized to trial counsel and the judge.Â  The judge held Rhoad in contempt and sentenced him to one year imprisonment consecutive to his current sentence.Â  Rhoad then exclaimed to the judge, â€œF**k you, you bastard.â€Â  The judge held Rhoad in contempt for that statement and sentenced him to another year consecutive to Rhoadâ€™s current sentence.Â  
On his way out of the courtroom, Rhoad apparently fought with the deputies, and he was brought back in to be chastised by the judge.Â  Although Rhoad denied that he was fighting with the deputies, the judge warned him that he would receive â€œanother yearâ€ if Rhoad raised his voice again.Â  Despite ordering two consecutive, one-year sentences for contempt at the hearing, the orders signed by the judge imposed two, six-month sentences for contempt on Rhoad to be served consecutively to his prior sentences and consecutively to each other.Â  This appeal followed. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
A determination of contempt ordinarily resides in the sound discretion of the trial court.Â  Whetstone v. Whetstone, 309 S.C. 227, 233, 420 S.E.2d 877, 880-81 (Ct. App. 1992).Â  â€œThis court will reverse a trial courtâ€™s decision regarding contempt only if it is without evidentiary support or is an abuse of discretion.Â  An abuse of discretion can occur where the trial courtâ€™s ruling is based on an error of law.â€Â  First Union Natâ€™l Bank v. First Citizens Bank & Trust Co. of South Carolina, 346 S.C. 462, 466, 551 S.E.2d 301, 303 (Ct. App. 2001) (citations omitted).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I. Â Finding of Contempt
Rhoad argues the judge erred in holding him in contempt for â€œgesturingâ€ at trial counsel as he walked out of the courtroom because: Â he apologized; his â€œjuvenileâ€ conduct was not disruptive; the gesture was not directed at the court; and he was not previously warned that such conduct would be considered contemptuous.[2]Â  We disagree. 
Inherent in all courts is the power to punish for contempt to preserve order and maintain decorum in judicial proceedings.Â  In re Diggs, 344 S.C. 434, 434, 544 S.E.2d 632, 632 (2001); Stone v. Reddix-Smalls, 295 S.C. 514, 516, 369 S.E.2d 840, 841 (1988) (â€œThe courtâ€™s power includes the ability to maintain order and decorum.â€). Â Contemptuous conduct in the presence of the court is direct contempt.Â  Brandt v. Gooding, 368 S.C. 618, 628, 630 S.E.2d 259, 264 (2006); State v. Kennerly, 337 S.C. 617, 620, 524 S.E.2d 837, 838 (1999).Â  â€œA person may be found guilty of direct contempt if his conduct interferes with judicial proceedings, exhibits disrespect for the court, or hampers parties or witnesses.â€Â  State v. Havelka, 285 S.C. 388, 389, 330 S.E.2d 288, 288 (1985). Â â€œDirect contempt that occurs in the courtâ€™s presence may be immediately adjudged and sanctioned summarily.â€Â  Brandt, 368 S.C. at 628, 630 S.E.2d at 264.Â  South Carolina courts have taken an expansive view of the â€œpresenceâ€ and â€œcourtâ€ requirements to encompass all elements of the judicial system, not just the mere physical presence of the judge or courtroom.Â  Kennerly, 337 S.C. at 620, 524 S.E.2d at 838.Â  
There is sufficient evidence in the record to support the judgeâ€™s finding of contempt for Rhoadâ€™s gesture.Â  Regardless of whether Rhoadâ€™s hearing had concluded, Rhoad failed to show proper decorum in the courtroom and exhibited a disrespect for the court so inherent that no warning of possible contempt was necessary.Â  It is irrelevant that the obscene gesture was not directed at the judge.Â  Despite Rhoadâ€™s argument that the â€œjuvenileâ€ gesture was not disruptive, the gesture interrupted courtroom proceedings and necessitated a hearing to address his actions.Â  Further, Rhoadâ€™s post-gesture apology did not change the fact that he failed to act with proper decorum in the presence of the judge.Â  Because there was sufficient evidence to support the judgeâ€™s finding of contempt for Rhoadâ€™s use of an obscene gesture, we find the judge did not abuse his discretion.
II.Â  Entitlement to a Jury Trial
Rhoad argues that his two, one-year consecutive sentences for contempt should be vacated because he was entitled to a jury trial pursuant to Codispoti v. Pennsylvania, 418 U.S. 506 (1974).Â  We disagree.
An accused is guaranteed the right of a speedy trial via the Sixth and Fourteenth Amendments to the Constitution.Â  Codispoti, 418 U.S. at 511.Â  Petty crimes can generally be tried without a jury trial, but serious crimes require a jury trial if the accused requests one.Â  Id.; Bloom v. Illinois, 391 U.S. 194, 209-10 (1968).Â  Courts normally look to the maximum punishment assigned by the legislature in determining whether a sentence is serious or petty.Â  Lewis v. United States, 518 U.S. 322, 326 (1996). Â Crimes with punishments of six months or less are presumably â€œpetty,â€ while crimes with punishments greater than six months are presumably â€œserious.â€Â  Id.Â  
Where the legislature fails to assign a maximum penalty, courts look to the â€œseverity of the penalty actually imposed as the measure of the character of the particular offense.â€Â  Lewis, 518 U.S. at 328; Codispoti, 418 U.S. at 511.Â  In noting the special concerns raised by criminal contempt matters, the Supreme Court has further noted that a jury trial is favorable in order to avoid the likelihood of arbitrary action by a judge in the potentially heated contempt context.Â  Lewis, 518 U.S. at 329.Â  Nevertheless, a contemnor may be tried without a jury under certain circumstances, as long as the sentence imposed is no longer than six months.Â  Codispoti, 418 U.S. at 514 (â€œUndoubtedly, where the necessity of circumstances warrants, a contemnor may be summarily tried for an act of contempt during trial and punished by a term of no more than six months.â€).
The South Carolina General Assembly has not assigned a maximum penalty for contempt in circuit court cases.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 14-5-320 (1976) (â€œThe circuit court may punish by fine or imprisonment, at the discretion of the court, all contempts of authority in any cause or hearing before the same.â€); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-25-30 (2003) (â€œIn cases of legal conviction when no punishment is provided by statute the court shall award such sentence as is conformable to the common usage and practice in this State, according to the nature of the offense, and not repugnant to the Constitution.â€).Â  Because the legislature has not imposed a maximum sentence on contempt, we look to the sentence Rhoad actually received to determine whether it could be characterized as â€œpettyâ€ or â€œserious.â€Â  Although Rhoad complains about the two, one-year consecutive sentences that were orally pronounced at the contempt hearing, the judgeâ€™s final order actually imposed two consecutive sentences of six months.Â  The two consecutive six-month sentences are the equivalent of a one-year sentence.Â  Thus, the sentences were such that would normally entitle a defendant to a jury trial if he or she requested one.Â  See Codispoti, 418 U.S. at 516-17 (looking to the sentence actually imposed, the Supreme Court held that because the defendantâ€™s consecutive, six-month sentences on seven counts of contempt amounted to a sentence of greater than three years, he was tried for the equivalent of a serious offense and was entitled to a jury trial). 
Nevertheless, we must affirm.Â  Rhoad cites Codispoti in arguing he was entitled to a jury trial.Â  However, the defendant in Codispoti requested, and was denied, a jury trial on his contempt charges.Â  Codispoti, 418 U.S. at 507-08.Â  Rhoad never requested a jury trial, and he never objected to the imposition of the contempt sentences without a jury trial.Â  Because Rhoad failed to request a jury trial and failed to object to the length of his sentence, this issue is not preserved for appellate review.Â  State v. Johnston, 333 S.C. 459, 462, 510 S.E.2d 423, 425 (1999) (holding that a sentence which exceeds the maximum allowable is not a question of subject matter jurisdiction; thus, unless an objection was made to the sentence at trial, the issue is not preserved for review); State v. Hicks, 330 S.C. 207, 216, 499 S.E.2d 209, 214 (1998) (holding that issues not raised to or ruled upon by the trial judge are not preserved for appellate review).
Thus, although there may be merit to the question of whether Rhoad was entitled to a jury trial, Rhoad was obligated to bring that issue to the attention of the judge.Â  Because he failed to do so, we may not address it.Â  State v. Passmore, 363 S.C. 568, 586, 611 S.E.2d 273, 283 (Ct. App. 2005) (holding that despite the fact that the defendant was sentenced to greater than six months for contempt without the benefit of a jury trial, defendant failed to object to the sentence and the issue was not preserved for appellate review), cert. denied (Sept. 7, 2006).[3]
CONCLUSION
The PCR judge did not abuse his discretion in holding Rhoad in contempt for making an obscene gesture at trial counsel at the end of the PCR hearing.Â  Rhoad did not appeal the finding of contempt for the profane outburst directed at the judge, and it is the law of the case.Â  Although Rhoad was entitled to a jury trial where the aggregate of his sentences for contempt exceeded six months, he did not request a jury trial nor did he object, and thus, that issue is not preserved for our review.Â  
Accordingly, Rhoadâ€™s convictions and sentences for contempt are 
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON and HUFF, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  Because oral argument would not aid the court in resolving the issues on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]Â  Rhoad does not complain about the finding of contempt for his profane outburst and admits in his brief that the outburst constituted classic contempt.Â  It is interesting to note that the gesture Rhoad used is commonly understood to have the same meaning as the words he used in his profane outburst.Â  In any event, because Rhoad failed to appeal the finding of contempt for the profane outburst, it is the law of the case.Â  State v. Sampson, 317 S.C. 423, 427, 454 S.E.2d 721, 723 (Ct. App. 1995) (holding that an unchallenged ruling, right or wrong, is the law of the case).
[3] We also note Rhoad complains that the oral sentences of one year on each count of contempt were unconstitutional and that the court erred by reducing them.Â  Judges are not bound by oral rulings and are free to issue written orders in conflict with prior oral rulings.Â  First Union Natâ€™l Bank of S.C. v. Hitman, Inc., 308 S.C. 421, 422, 418 S.E.2d 545, 545 (1992).Â  Until an order is written and entered, the judge is free to change his mind and amend prior rulings.Â  Ford v. State Ethics Commâ€™n, 344 S.C. 642, 646, 545 S.E.2d 821, 823 (2001) (â€œUntil written and entered, the trial judge retains the discretion to change his mind and amend his oral ruling accordingly.â€).Â  Because the final sentence imposed on each count of contempt was six months, there is no factual basis to support Rhoadâ€™s complaint regarding the consecutive one-year sentences.Â  Even if Rhoadâ€™s argument could be construed as a complaint that the two consecutive six-month sentences were unconstitutional, we have previously found Rhoadâ€™s failure to request a jury trial or to object to the sentence rendered this argument not preserved for appellate review.Â  Passmore, 363 S.C. at 586, 611 S.E.2d at 283.

In applying standards for admissibility, a number of courts differentiate between a dog handlerâ€™s expert opinion based on experience-based knowledge and an expert opinion based on scientific evidence that requires a Daubert analysis.Â  The Virginia Appellate Court held empirical evidence provided by a K9 officer sufficiently established a dogâ€™s reliability without requiring evidence of a scientific basis for the dogâ€™s ability to track a scent.Â  Pelletier v. Com., 592 S.E.2d 382, 388 (Va. Ct. App. 2004).Â  The court emphasized:Â  â€œAn expertâ€™s testimony is admissible not only when scientific knowledge is required, but when experience and observation in a special calling give the expert knowledge of a subject beyond common intelligence and ordinary experience.â€Â  Id.Â  For instance, â€œthe typical police officer qualifies as an expert based on his experience with narcotics, not on his ability to explain the scientific theory behind his opinion.â€Â  Id. 
 The Colorado Supreme Court ruled â€œdog scent trailing evidenceâ€ was admissibleâ€ if foundational requirements were satisfied, and â€œneither the Frye nor Daubert standards of general acceptance or scientific reliability applied.â€Â  Brooks v. People, 975 P.2d 1105, 1111 (Colo. 1999).Â  Distinguishing between scientific knowledge based on the scientific method and experience-based, specialized knowledge, the court declined to apply factors designed to ascertain scientific validity in analyzing dog tracking evidence.Â  Id. at 1113.Â  â€œ[W]e hold that testimony pertaining to scent tracking by a trained police dog is not readily subjected to standards which were not designed with experience-based specialized knowledge in mind.â€ Â Id. at 1115.Â  The court further reasoned the proper analysis of reliability in dog tracking cases was based on Rule 702 of the Colorado Rules of Evidence (CRE) admissibility standards. 
In State v. Bourassa, 399 A.2d 507 (Vt. 1979), the Vermont Supreme Court dismissed a defendantâ€™s contention that dog tracking testimony was inadmissible because the scientific principles underlying such testimony were not established in the record.Â  The court held evidence in the record was sufficient to find that a â€œwell trained dog, supervised by an experienced handler and working under reasonable conditions, is capable of trailing a human being accurately.â€ Id. at 510.Â  Agreeing with the majority of jurisdictions, the court concluded the foundation sufficiently established that: (1) the handler was qualified to use the dog; (2) the dog was trained and accurate in tracking humans; (3) the dog was placed on the trail where circumstances indicate that the accused had been; and (4) the trail had not become so stale or contaminated that it was beyond the dogâ€™s tracking capabilities. Â Id. at 511;Â  accord Reisch v. State, 628 A.2d 84 (Del. 1993) (deciding scientific testing not required to support evidence obtained by a dog if foundational requirements are met); People v. Roraback, 662 N.Y.S.2d 327 (N.Y. App. Div. 1997) (holding the use of a trained dog is an investigative rather than scientific procedure); Winston v. State, 78 S.W.3d 522, 526 (Tex. Ct. App. 2002) (finding interpretation of a dogâ€™s reaction to a scent lineup is based upon training and experience, and not on scientific methodology). 
D. Â Â Â Â  The Extant Factual Record
The underlying rationale in Pelletier, Brooks, and Bourassa comports with our Supreme Courtâ€™s analysis in State v. Whaley, 305 S.C. 138, 406 S.E.2d 369 (1991).Â  The Whaley courtâ€™s distinction between scientific evidence requiring a Jones analysis and expert testimony based on specialized knowledge and experience is equally applicable in the instant case.Â  
Gunterâ€™s testimony established the proper foundation under State v. Childs, 299 S.C. 471, 477, 385 S.E.2d 839, 843 (1989) for admitting his opinion as to the reliability of dog tracking evidence.Â  The officer had been with the Columbia Police Department for nearly fourteen years, working as a K9 handler and trainer.Â  He had attained the rank of Senior Master K9 Handler and assisted with the training of other K9 handlers and dogs in the department. Â Initially, Gunter trained with the Columbia Police Department in 1991.Â  He holds a membership in the American Association of K9 Trainers and maintains his certification by attending week-long training sessions annually. Â Additionally, while his dog, Aurie, was in service, he trained weekly with the K9 unit of the Columbia Police Department. Â Gunterâ€™s partnership with Aurie lasted over seven years, the entire duration of the dogâ€™s career.Â  During that time the team engaged in approximately 750 tracking excursions.Â  
Gunter opined that Aurie was â€œvery reliable.â€Â  The dog was a German shepherd, who had descended from a bloodline of known police and militaryÂ Â  working dogs.Â  He was certified in tracking, article searches, building searches, protection, and obedience.Â  However, Gunter emphasized Aurieâ€™s strongest skill was tracking people.Â  
White advanced his objection to the admission of the dog tracking evidence on the ground it was not scientifically reliable and did not meet the standards set forth in State v. Jones, 273 S.C. 723, 259 S.E.2d 120, (1979) concerning scientific evidence.Â  Addressing Whiteâ€™s challenge outside of the juryâ€™s presence, the trial judge explained:

  
    The Court:  
    Well, you know, not all expert testimony deals with scientific evidence.
  
  
    White’s Counsel:
    Yes, sir.  We do understand but we do feel that if they are using it, they are qualifying his as an expert if he—the evidence should meet the standards of scientific evidence, your honor.
  
  
     The Court: 
    Well, even if it’s not a scientific evidence that they are offering?
  
  
    White’s Counsel: 
    Your Honor, any evidence he is offering as an expert—
  
  
    The Court: 
    Well, expert is scientific, technical, or other specialized knowledge.  Doesn’t have to be scientific or technical. 
  

Accordingly, the trial court ruled Gunter could offer his opinion testimony as to the reliability of what tracking dogs do provided the State laid the proper foundation.Â  Based on testimony about the extent of Gunterâ€™s training and experience, Aurieâ€™s acuity and skill in tracking human scent, and Gunterâ€™s assessment of Aurieâ€™s reliability, the trial court instructed the jury:

  Iâ€™m going to find the officer qualified as an expert in the field of K9 tracking and handling with respect to his dog and the dogs in general.Â  Ladies and gentlemen, if scientific, technical, or other specialized knowledge will assist you, the trier of fact, in understanding any issue that isâ€”any fact thatâ€™s in issue or any evidence that may be an issue, then a person who is qualified by virtue of his or her knowledge, skill, experience, training or education may be qualified as an expert in that particular field. 
  Iâ€™m going to find the officer to be qualified as I said in the area of animal or dog tracking and handling, and as such he can offer opinions in his area of expertise.
  Now, you are to give his testimony such weight and credibility as you deem appropriate as you will with any and all witnesses that will testify in this trial.Â Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  

Gunterâ€™s testimony verified he had acquired, by training and experience, such knowledge and skill in the area of dog handling and tracking that rendered him better qualified than the jury to form an opinion on the particular subject of dog tracking. Â Furthermore, Gunterâ€™s testimony was based on his specialized knowledge, skill, and experience in the use of a scent-tracking dog, rather than on the validity of dog tracking as a scientific procedure. Â The nature of Gunterâ€™s testimony is analogous to that offered by a typical police officer who qualifies as an expert based on his experience with narcotics, not on his ability to explain the scientific theory behind his opinion.Â  As such, the evidence Gunter provided complies with Rule 702, SCRE by helping the jury understand the evidence or resolve a factual issue. Â As the Whaley court indicated, when a proper foundation is established, a Jones analysis is not warranted if expert testimony is based on specialized skill or knowledge rather than on scientific techniques. Â See State Â v. Whaley, 305 S.C. 138, 406 S.E.2d 369 (1991).Â  Furthermore, the trial court cautioned the jury that questions about the reliability of Gunterâ€™s methods go only to the weight of his testimony, not the admissibility.Â  See State v. Morgan, 326 S.C. 503, 485 S.E.2d 112 (Ct. App. 1997).
E.Â Â Â Â Â  Harmless Error
Though we discern no error in the trial courtâ€™s qualification of Gunter as an expert witness, the admission of his opinion testimony, if error, was harmless.Â  Pursuant to Rule 103, SCRE, â€œ[e]rror may not be predicated upon a ruling which admits or excludes evidence unless a substantial right of the party is affected . . . .â€
No definite rule of law governs finding an error harmless; rather, the materiality and prejudicial character of the error must be determined from its relationship to the entire case.Â  State v. Gillian, 360 S.C. 433, 454-55, 602 S.E.2d 62, 73 (Ct. App. 2004) (citing State v. Reeves, 301 S.C. 191, 391 S.E.2d 241 (1990); State v. Mitchell, 286 S.C. 572, 336 S.E.2d 150 (1985); State v. Curry, 370 S.C. 674, 636 S.E.2d 649 (Ct. App. 2006); State v. Pagan, 357 S.C. 132, 591 S.E.2d 646 (Ct. App. 2004)). Â Whether an error is harmless depends on the particular facts of each case, including:

  the importance of the witnessâ€™ testimony in the prosecutionâ€™s case, whether the testimony was cumulative, the presence or absence of evidence corroborating or contradicting the testimony of the witness on material points, the extent of cross-examination otherwise permitted, and of course the overall strength of the prosecutionâ€™s case.

State v. Mizzell, 349 S.C. 326, 333, 563 S.E.2d 315, 318-19 (2002) (quoting Delaware v. Van Arsdall, 475 U.S. 673, 684, 106 S. Ct. 1431, 89 L.Ed.2d 674 (1986)).
â€œHarmless beyond a reasonable doubtâ€ means the reviewing court can conclude the error did not contribute to the verdict beyond a reasonable doubt. Â Mizzell, 349 S.C. at 334, 563 S.E.2d at 319; Arnold v. State, 309 S.C. 157, 420 S.E.2d 834 (1992). Â â€œIn determining whether an error is harmless, the reviewing court must review the entire record to determine what effect the error had on the verdict.â€ Â Mizzell, 349 S.C. at 334, 563 S.E.2d at 319 (internal quotations omitted).
Error is harmless where it could not reasonably have affected the result of the trial. Â In re Harvey, 355 S.C. 53, 584 S.E.2d 893 (2003); Mitchell, 286 S.C. at 573, 336 S.E.2d at 151; State v. Burton, 326 S.C. 605, 486 S.E.2d 762 (Ct. App. 1997). Â Generally, appellate courts will not set aside convictions due to insubstantial errors not affecting the result. Â State v. Sherard, 303 S.C. 172, 399 S.E.2d 595 (1991); State v. Adams, 354 S.C. 361, 580 S.E.2d 785 (Ct. App. 2003). Â Thus, an insubstantial error not affecting the result of the trial is harmless where guilt has been conclusively proven by competent evidence such that no other rational conclusion can be reached. Â State v. Bailey, 298 S.C. 1, 377 S.E.2d 581 (1989); Adams, 354 S.C. at 381, 580 S.E.2d at 795; see also State v. Primus, 349 S.C. 576, 564 S.E.2d 103 (2002) (holding assistant solicitorâ€™s improper comment, during closing argument was harmless error, where evidence of guilt was overwhelming) overruled on other grounds; State v. Kelley, 319 S.C. 173, 460 S.E.2d 368 (1995) (noting that when guilt is conclusively proven by competent evidence, such that no other rational conclusion could be reached, this court will not set aside conviction for insubstantial errors not affecting result). 
Ample evidence linked White to the crimes charged.Â  The testimonies of the victim, Gwen Anthony, and co-defendant, Anthony Morris, were corroborated by a surveillance videotape that recorded the crime as it unfolded.Â  In addition, Roy Wiggins, the driver of the escape car, testified against White.Â  Items taken from the crime scene were located in the escape vehicle.Â  Officer Rouppasong witnessed a man carrying something in his hand and wearing dark jeans and a white shirt run from the Circle K parking lot.Â  In pursuit, the officer lost sight of the man briefly and then came upon the escape car.Â  The same man wearing the dark jeans and white shirt ran from the escape car toward the yard of the residence where White was eventually found.Â  Gunter put his tracking dog on the scent at the location where the man exited the vehicle.Â  The area in which the dog began tracking had been secured in order to preserve evidence.Â  The dogâ€™s tracks led to the location where White was discovered.Â  He appeared to be asleep and was clutching a gun in his hand.Â  The gun matched Anthonyâ€™s description of the weapon the robber carried, and both Morris and Wiggins positively identified it as the gun White had in his possession immediately prior to the robbery.Â  
The evidentiary record reflects other substantial evidence of Whiteâ€™s guilt without the inclusion of Gunterâ€™s testimony.Â  Consequently, the admission of the dog tracking evidence was cumulative and harmless.Â Â Â  
II.Â Â Â Â  Newly Discovered Evidence
White claims newly discovered evidence entitles him to a new trial.Â  We disagree.Â  
After White served his notice of appeal, co-defendant Anthony Morris issued a written statement retracting his trial testimony against White.Â  Morris claimed he was not at the scene of the crime.Â  In a motion to this court, White urged that we either remand the case for a new trial or remand the case to the trial court for a hearing on the purported new evidence.Â  The State opposed and this court denied the motion. Â The State argues this court should not consider Morrisâ€™ statement because it has not been raised to and ruled on by the trial court and is not properly before this court.Â  We agree. 
Rule 29(b), SCRCrimP, governs post trial motions on after discovered evidence.Â  A motion for a new trial based on after discovered evidence may not be made while the case is on appeal unless the appellate court exercises its discretionary authority, suspends the appeal, and grants leave to proceed in the circuit court.Â  The lack of a ruling from the trial court presents nothing for this courtâ€™s review.Â  
Furthermore, a brief must reference the Record on Appeal to support the facts alleged.Â  Rule 207(b)(4), SCACR.Â  â€œThe Record shall not, however, include matter which was not presented to the lower court or tribunal.â€Â  Rule 210(c), SCACR.Â  Morrisâ€™ statement was not presented to the lower court and cannot be properly included in the Record on Appeal.Â  
CONCLUSION
We rule that dog tracking evidence is recognized in South Carolina.Â  We hold that dog tracking evidence is not required to meet the scientific evidence standard articulated in State v. Jones, 273 S.C. 723, 259 S.E.2d 120, (1979).Â  We conclude that dog tracking evidence is admissible provided the dog handlerâ€™s knowledge, skill, experience, and training qualifies the handler in the area of dog handling and dog tracking.Â  In the case sub judice, Gunterâ€™s specialized knowledge, skill, experience, and training qualified him to offer his opinion in the area of dog handling and dog tracking.Â  Luculently, the testimony of Gunter complies with expert testimony law extant in South Carolina.Â  
There is no error in the trial courtâ€™s qualification of Gunter as an expert witness and the admission of his opinion testimony.Â  Assumptively concluding that error exists, the error is harmless beyond a reasonable doubt.Â  There is overwhelming evidence in the trial record without the inclusion or consideration of Gunterâ€™s testimony to support the convictions of the Appellant.
The Appellantâ€™s claim as to the right to a new trial based on newly discovered evidence is dismissed based on procedural grounds. 
Accordingly, the trial courtâ€™s ruling is 
AFFIRMED.
HUFF and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        David H. Barton, Employee Claimant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        William Ian Higgs d/b/a Iyanel Enterprises and Total Home Exteriors, Inc., Employers, and Key Risk Insurance and SC Uninsured Employersâ€™ Fund, Carrier Defendants,
        Of Whom Total Home Exteriors, Inc., Employers and Key Risk Insurance are the Respondents,
        And SC Uninsured Employersâ€™ Fund is the Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â D. Garrison Hill, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4197
Submitted January 1, 2007 â€“ Filed January 16, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      Amy V. Cofield and Terry M. Mauldin, both of Lexington; LaTonya Edwards, of Columbia, for Appellant.
      Michael A. Farry, and David A. Wilson, both of Greenville, for Respondents.
    
  

ANDERSON, J.:Â  In this workersâ€™ compensation case, the South Carolina Uninsured Employersâ€™ Fund (the Fund) appeals the finding of the Appellate Panel of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission that the contractor was entitled to transfer liability to the Fund under section 42-1-415 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005) because the contractor collected documentation of its subcontractorâ€™s insurance on â€œa standard form acceptable to the commission.â€Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
William Higgs, doing business as Iyanel Enterprises (Iyanel), served as the roofing subcontractor for Total Home Exteriors, Inc. (Total Home) for nine years.Â  One of the jobs Iyanel worked on for Total Home was in the Keowee Keys subdivision in Seneca.Â  Iyanel paid for insurance coverage through Jackie Perry Insurance Agency in Anderson and received an unsigned Certificate of Insurance evidencing workersâ€™ compensation and employerâ€™s liability insurance for September 13, 2003 through September 13, 2004.Â  When Iyanel was initially engaged to perform the work at Keowee Keys, it presented Total Home with the Certificate of Insurance. Â The record indicates Iyanel paid for the insurance and an employee of the Jackie Perry agency issued Certificates of Insurance without coverage being bound.Â  
David Barton, an employee of Iyanel, was injured when he fell from a roof at the Keowee Keys job and as a result, filed a workersâ€™ compensation claim.Â  At the time of the accident, despite Iyanelâ€™s belief to the contrary, the business did not have workersâ€™ compensation coverage.Â  The single commissioner found Barton had suffered a compensable injury and that Total Home was a statutory employer liable for compensation under section 42-1-410 of the South Carolina Code (1985).Â  The single commissioner further found that under section 42-1-415, Total Home had no ultimate liability because it relied in good faith on Iyanelâ€™s Certificate of Insurance and transferred responsibility for the workersâ€™ compensation benefits to the Fund.Â  
The Fund appealed to the Appellate Panel, which affirmed the single commissionerâ€™s order and incorporated it by reference.Â  On appeal, the circuit court affirmed the Appellate Panel.[2]Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The South Carolina Administrative Procedures Act (APA) establishes the standard for judicial review of decisions by the Appellate Panel.Â  Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 134-35, 276 S.E.2d 304, 306 (1981); Hargrove v. Titan Textile Co., 360 S.C. 276, 288, 599 S.E.2d 604, 610 (Ct. App. 2004); Gibson v. Spartanburg Sch. Dist. No. 3, 338 S.C. 510, 516, 526 S.E.2d 725, 728 (Ct. App. 2000). Â Under the scope of review established in the APA, this court may not substitute its judgment for that of the Appellate Panel as to the weight of the evidence on questions of fact, but may reverse where the decision is affected by an error of law. Â Stone v. Traylor Bros., Inc., 360 S.C. 271, 274, 600 S.E.2d 551, 552 (Ct. App. 2004); Frame v. Resort Servs., Inc., 357 S.C. 520, 527, 593 S.E.2d 491, 495 (Ct. App. 2004); Stephen v. Avins Constr. Co., 324 S.C. 334, 337, 478 S.E.2d 74, 76 (Ct. App. 1996).
The substantial evidence rule governs the standard of review in a workersâ€™ compensation decision. Â Frame, 357 S.C. at 527, 593 S.E.2d at 494. Â The Appellate Panelâ€™s decision must be affirmed if supported by substantial evidence in the record.Â  Shuler v. Gregory Elec., 366 S.C. 435, 440, 622 S.E.2d 569, 571 (Ct. App. 2005) (citing Sharpe v. Case Produce, Inc., 336 S.C. 154, 160, 519 S.E.2d 102, 105 (1999)).Â  An appellate court can reverse or modify the Appellate Panelâ€™s decision only if the appellantâ€™s substantial rights have been prejudiced because the decision is affected by an error of law or is â€œclearly erroneous in view of the reliable, probative and substantial evidence on the whole record.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6) (2005); Â Bursey v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control, 360 S.C. 135, 141, 600 S.E.2d 80, 84 (Ct. App. 2004). 

  â€œSubstantial evidenceâ€ is not a mere scintilla of evidence nor the evidence viewed blindly from one side of the case, but is evidence which, considering the record as a whole, would allow reasonable minds to reach the conclusion that the administrative agency reached or must have reached in order to justify its action.

Lark, 276 S.C. at 135, 276 S.E.2d at 306; see also Pratt v. Morris Roofing, Inc., 357 S.C. 619, 623, 594 S.E.2d 272, 274 (2004); Jones v. Ga.-Pac. Corp., 355 S.C. 413, 417, 586 S.E.2d 111, 113 (2003); Etheredge v. Monsanto Co., 349 S.C. 451, 456, 562 S.E.2d 679, 681-82 (Ct. App. 2002); Broughton v. S. of the Border, 336 S.C. 488, 495, 520 S.E.2d 634, 637 (Ct. App. 1999). Â 
â€œ[T]he possibility of drawing two inconsistent conclusions from the evidence does not prevent an administrative agencyâ€™s finding from being supported by substantial evidence.â€Â  Palmetto Alliance, Inc. v. S.C. Pub. Serv. Commâ€™n, 282 S.C. 430, 432, 319 S.E.2d 695, 696 (1984); see also Sharpe, 336 S.C. at 160, 519 S.E.2d at 105; DuRant v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control, 361 S.C. 416, 420, 604 S.E.2d 704, 707 (Ct. App. 2004); Corbin v. Kohler Co., 351 S.C. 613, 618, 571 S.E.2d 92, 95 (Ct. App. 2002); Muir v. C.R. Bard, Inc., 336 S.C. 266, 282, 519 S.E.2d 583, 591 (Ct. App. 1999). Â Where the evidence is conflicting over a factual issue, the findings of the Appellate Panel are conclusive. Â Hargrove, 360 S.C. at 290, 599 S.E.2d at 611; Etheredge, 349 S.C. at 455, 562 S.E.2d at 681.Â  In workersâ€™ compensation cases, the Appellate Panel is the ultimate finder of fact.Â  Shealy v. Aiken County, 341 S.C. 448, 455, 535 S.E.2d 438, 442 (2000); Bass v. Isochem, 365 S.C. 454, 468, 617 S.E.2d 369, 376 (Ct. App. 2005); Muir, 336 S.C. at 282, 519 S.E.2d at 591. Â â€œThe final determination of witness credibility and the weight to be accorded evidence is reserved to the Appellate Panel.â€ Â Frame, 357 S.C. at 528, 593 S.E.2d at 495 (citing Shealy v. Aiken County, 341 S.C. 448, 535 S.E.2d 438 (2000); Parsons v. Georgetown Steel, 318 S.C. 63, 456 S.E.2d 366 (1995); Gibson, 338 S.C. at 517, 526 S.E.2d at 729). Â The findings of an administrative agency are presumed correct and will be set aside only if unsupported by substantial evidence. Â Anderson v. Baptist Med. Ctr., 343 S.C. 487, 492, 541 S.E.2d 526, 528 (2001); Hicks v. Piedmont Cold Storage, Inc., 335 S.C. 46, 48, 515 S.E.2d 532, 533 (1999). 
LAW/ANALYSIS
The Fund argues the circuit court erred in affirming the Appellate Panelâ€™s finding Total Home was entitled to transfer liability to the Fund under section 42-1-415 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005).Â  The Fund contends that because the certificate Iyanel presented to Total Home was unsigned, Total Home failed to comply with all the statutory provisions.Â  We disagree.
Section 42-1-415 provides:

  (A) Notwithstanding any other provision of law, upon the submission of documentation to the commission that a . . . subcontractor has represented himself to a higher tier . . . contractor . . . as having workersâ€™ compensation insurance at the time the . . . subcontractor was engaged to perform work, the higher tier . . . contractor . . . must be relieved of any and all liability under this title except as specifically provided in this section. Â In the event that employer is uninsured, regardless of the number of employees that employer has, the higher tier . . . contractor . . . or his insurance carrier shall in the first instance pay all benefits due under this title. Â The higher tier . . . contractor . . . or his insurance carrier may petition the commission to transfer responsibility for continuing compensation and benefits to the Uninsured Employersâ€™ Fund. Â The Uninsured Employersâ€™ Fund shall assume responsibility for claims within thirty days of a determination of responsibility made by the commission. Â The higher tier . . . contractor . . . must be reimbursed from the Uninsured Employersâ€™ Fund as created by Section 42-7-200 for compensation and medical benefits as may be determined by the commission. Â Any disputes arising as a result of claims filed under this section must be determined by the commission.
   (B) To qualify for reimbursement under this section, the higher tier . . . contractor . . . must collect documentation of insurance as provided in subsection (A) on a standard form acceptable to the commission. Â The documentation must be collected at the time the contractor or subcontractor is engaged to perform work and must be turned over to the commission at the time a claim is filed by the injured employee.

â€œUnder subsection 42-1-415(A), a statutory employer . . . may transfer liability to the fund when a subcontractorâ€™s employee is injured if the statutory employer submits documentation to the fund that the subcontractor has represented himself as having workersâ€™ compensation coverage â€˜at the time the . . . subcontractor was engaged to perform work.â€™â€Â  S.C. Uninsured Employerâ€™s Fund v. House, 360 S.C. 468, 471, 602 S.E.2d 81, 82 (Ct. App. 2004); see also Harrell v. Pineland Plantation, Ltd., 337 S.C. 313, 330, 523 S.E.2d 766, 774-75 (1999) (noting that pursuant to section 42-1-415(A), â€œa statutory employer is no longer directly liable for workersâ€™ compensation payments whenever documentation is presented to the commission that a contractor or subcontractor represented himself to the statutory employer as having workersâ€™ compensation insuranceâ€).Â  
Total Home met all of the statutory requirements to transfer liability: Â (1) a subcontractor, Iyanel, represented to Total Home, a higher tier contractor, that it had workersâ€™ compensation insurance at the time it was engaged to perform work; and (2) Total Home collected documentation of insurance on a standard form acceptable to the commission at the time Iyanel was engaged to perform work.Â  The Fundâ€™s sole contention is that because the Certificate of Insurance was unsigned, Total Home does not meet the statutory requirement for documentation of insurance.Â  However, the statute does not require a signed Certificate of Insurance.Â  It merely states, â€œa standard form acceptable to the commission.â€ Â 
â€œThe construction of a statute by the agency charged with its administration will be accorded the most respectful consideration and will not be overruled absent compelling reasons.â€Â  Dunton v. S.C. Bd. of Examâ€™rs in Optometry, 291 S.C. 221, 223, 353 S.E.2d 132, 133 (1987); see also Buist v. Huggins, 367 S.C. 268, 276, 625 S.E.2d 636, 640 (2006); Daisy Outdoor Adver. Co. v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Transp., 352 S.C. 113, 120, 572 S.E.2d 462, 466 (Ct. App. 2002). Â Further, â€œ[w]here the terms of the statute are clear, the court must apply those terms according to their literal meaning.â€Â  Brown v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control, 348 S.C. 507, 560 S.E.2d 410 (2002) (citing Paschal v. State Election Commâ€™n, 317 S.C. 434, 436, 454 S.E.2d 890, 892 (1995)); see also Hodges v. Rainey, 341 S.C. 79, 85, 533 S.E.2d 578, 581 (2000) (â€œWhere the statuteâ€™s language is plain and unambiguous, and conveys a clear and definite meaning, the rules of statutory interpretation are not needed and the court has no right to impose another meaning.â€).Â  Â Â 
The statute gives the commission the discretion of determining what is an acceptable form.Â  The Appellate Panel found Iyanelâ€™s Certificate of Insurance to be a â€œform acceptable to the Commission.â€Â  This finding was not in contravention of the literal meaning of the statute.Â  Accordingly, we give the proper deference to the Appellate Panel in interpreting the statute.Â  There is no compelling reason to differ with this interpretation of an acceptable form.
The Fund argues Regulation 67-415(A) of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005) provides the only acceptable document to demonstrate insurance.Â  The Regulation provides:

  For purposes of Section 42-1-415, the ACORD Form 25-S, Certificate of Insurance, as published by the ACORD Corporation and as issued by the insurance carrier for the insured, shall serve as documentation of insurance.Â  The Certificate of Insurance must be dated, signed, and issued by an authorized representative of the insurance carrier for the insured.Â  

Id.Â  However, the Fund mischaracterizes the Regulation.Â  The Regulation describes a document that is always accepted by the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission but does not prevent the Appellate Panel from finding other documentation acceptable.Â  Additionally, were we only to allow, as documentation of insurance, Certificates of Insurance that are signed, dated, and issued by an authorized representative of the insurance carrier for the insured, the upper-tier contractor could not look at the Certificate and discern whether it would be protected.Â  It would have to verify that the representative that issued the Certificate is authorized by the insurance carrier.Â  The legislature did not intend to put such a burden on contractors.
The Fund acknowledges the legislature created section 42-1-415 to provide relief for misled statutory employers.Â  Iyanel was exploited by its insurance company and, thus, unknowingly victimized Total Home.Â Â  The record contains no evidence that Total Home did not act in good faith.Â  Therefore, Total Home is exactly whom the legislature intended to protect when it enacted the statute. 
CONCLUSION
Total Home met all of the requirements in section 42-1-415 of the South Carolina Code to transfer liability to the Fund.Â  Although the Certificate of Insurance was unsigned, the Appellate Panel found the Certificate of Insurance to be acceptable.Â  Accordingly, the circuit courtâ€™s portion of the order affirming the Appellate Panel is 
AFFIRMED.
HUFF and BEATTY, JJ., concur

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] Barton appealed to the Appellate Panel and circuit court.Â  The Appellate Panel affirmed the single commissioner, but the circuit court reversed the Appellate Panel on one of Bartonâ€™s issues on appeal regarding terminating weekly benefits.Â  The issues that Barton appealed are not involved in this appeal.Â Â

description: The Vestry and Church Wardens of the Church of the Holy Cross brought this action against Orkin Exterminating Company  based on termite damage to its historic church building.  Holy Cross appeals from an order of the circuit court denying its motion for a new trial based on juror misconduct.
