THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        The Vestry and Church Wardens of the Church of the Holy Cross, a South Carolina Corporation, Inc., Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Orkin Exterminating Company, Inc., Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Sumter County
Â Thomas W. Cooper, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4198
Heard December 5, 2006 â€“ Filed January 16, 2007Â Â Â  

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
        Thomas S. Tisdale, Jr. and David J. Parrish, both of Charleston, for Appellant.
        Wade R. Marrionneaux, of Atlanta, Georgia; J. Rutledge Young, III and John Massalon, both of Charleston; and Kenneth R. Young, of Sumter, for Respondent.
      
    
  

GOOLSBY, J.:Â  This action arises out of a termite contract that the Church of the Holy Cross had with Orkin Exterminating Company and the discovery by Holy Cross that a termite infestation had damaged its historic church building.Â  The jury found for Orkin after a long trial involving issues related to the construction of the church building, the adequacy of annual inspections conducted by Orkin, the degree of termite damage sustained by the church building, and the cost of repairing the damage.Â  Holy Cross appeals the denial of its motion for a new trial based on juror misconduct.Â  We reverse and remand for a new trial.
At the start of the trial, the trial judge instructed the jurors that they should not discuss the case among themselves, should not discuss the case with anyone else, and should not attempt to investigate the case on their own.Â  A day after the trial ended in a jury verdict in Orkinâ€™s favor, an alternate juror contacted the trial judge and told him that â€œpossibleâ€ misconduct by one of the jurors had occurred during the trial of the case. Â The report prompted the trial judge to meet with the alternate juror to discuss her allegations.Â  Afterward, the trial judge addressed a letter to all counsel apprising them of the alternate jurorâ€™s allegations, allegations that in no way implicated either party or suggested wrongdoing by either party.Â  Â 
Â According to the letter, the alleged misconduct, which the alternate juror later confirmed under oath, consisted of the offending juror â€œearly in the trial . . . question[ing] aloud the instructions that she was not to talk about the case . . . because everybody knew what was going onâ€; commenting to the other jurors â€œthat everyone knew that the historic people â€˜have moneyâ€™ and are simply trying to get someone else to â€˜pay their billsâ€™ â€ and â€œthat â€˜old buildings fall downâ€™ simply because of ageâ€; telling the other jurors â€œthat she did not know why she had to hear both sides of the case and that she had discussed it with her mother who reaffirmed that the historic people have money and should clean up their own messâ€; remarking to the other jurors that she had talked with a painter friend who told her that walls could collapse due to hidden termite damage; declaring to the other jurors â€œthat they should tear down the church and bring in a double wideâ€; indicating to the other jurors â€œthat she had talked with her minister about the situationâ€ but then retracting her statement â€œto say that she and the minister simply prayed about her service and she had asked for guidance in making a decisionâ€; and disclosing to the other jurors that she had gone out to the church and looked at it and that it â€œlooked fine to her.â€Â  The jurors reportedly admonished the offending juror about discussing the case, â€œlaughed offâ€ her comments, â€œ[told] her to stop,â€ and â€œpaid her no attention.â€ Â Â 
Upon learning of the alternate jurorâ€™s allegations, Holy Cross moved for a new trial based on juror misconduct.Â  
The trial judge later conducted a hearing at which he summoned Â the jurors to appear. Â After questioning the jurors in the presence of counsel for both parties regarding the allegations made by the alternate juror, the trial judge held the comments and actions by the offending juror did not prejudice Holy Cross in such a way as to â€œaffect[ ] the impartiality of the verdictâ€ and that â€œ[i]n fact, all other jurors[1] indicated that her actions had no impact on their individual decisions.â€[2] Â Whereupon, the trial judge denied the motion by Holy Cross for a new trial.Â  In a separate order, the trial judge held the offending juror in criminal contempt for â€œmaking impermissible comments to other jurors prior to the juryâ€™s proper deliberations.â€ 
The basic issue here, as we see it, is whether the juror misconduct in question affected Holy Crossâ€™ right to fundamental fairness at trial.[3]Â  More to the point, did the juror misconduct at issue in this case so affect the juryâ€™s impartiality as to deprive Holy Cross of a fair trial?[4]Â  We recognize that what constitutes improper juror behavior as will warrant a new trial must be determined by the facts and circumstances of each case.[5]Â  
The trial judge here mainly focused, particularly in his questioning of jurors, not upon the offending juror but upon the other eleven and the effect that the offending jurorâ€™s comments and actions had upon them.Â  The question, however, of whether the offending jurorâ€™s comments and actions had any influence upon the other jurors is not the sole determining factor as to whether the misconduct warrants a new trial.Â  A jury, after all, is composed of twelve, not eleven, jurors, and it acts as a unit[6]; thus, â€œthe misconduct of any juror, actual or implied, which . . . prevents a fair and proper consideration of the case is misconduct of the entire jury, vitiating its verdict and requiring a new trial.â€[7]Â  
In this case, the offending juror pointedly ignored the trial judgeâ€™s admonition for the jury to refrain from discussing the case until both sides could be heard from.Â  Aside from engaging in discussions with at least three outsiders about the case, the offending juror made statements to her fellow jurors early on and before the submission of the case about matters that were not based on the evidence, that manifested views openly hostile to Holy Cross, and that, one may reasonably presume, influenced her.[8]Â  Moreover, she undertook her own investigation into the facts when she drove out to the church without the authority of the court or the consent of the parties.
The prohibition against jurors discussing a case until the trial judge submits it to them for deliberation and decision[9] involves, our supreme court has held, a matter of fundamental fairness.[10]Â  The prohibition is meant to insure that jurors remain impartial throughout the entire trial and that they hear both sides of a controversy before making up their minds and rendering a verdict.Â  There are, after all, at least two sides to every story.
An examination or investigation by a juror conducted without the authority of the court or consent of the parties of a place or object that is the subject of conflicting evidence may provide a basis for a new trial.[11]Â  Although she may not have learned anything from her visit to the site that she did not already know and her report to the other jurors of her actions may not have had any impact on them, the offending jurorâ€™s attempt to conduct an unsanctioned investigation into the facts of this case, when viewed with her other acts and comments, shows a juror unconcerned about granting Holy Cross the fair and impartial trial to which it was entitled.[12]Â  
A fair and impartial juror the offending juror clearly was not, particularly since it appears she made up her mind early on in the trial and before presentation of all the evidence. 
We therefore hold that under the circumstances of this case, which involves several acts of juror misconduct and where at least one of those acts was deemed so egregious by the trial judge that he punished the offending juror for criminal contempt, the failure of the trial judge to grant a new trial based upon those acts of misconduct amounts to an abuse of discretion.[13]Â  While we recognize the burden our decision places upon Orkin, which bears no responsibility for what occurred, we believe fundamental fairness demands Holy Cross be given a new trial.[14] 
REVERSED and REMANDED.
KITTREDGE, J., concurs.Â  STILWELL, J., dissents in a separate opinion.
STILWELL, J., (dissenting):Â  I respectfully dissent.
The focus of the majority opinion is principally upon the one juror who unquestionably is guilty of misconduct and violated the clear instructions of the court.Â  
However, I believe, as did the trial judge, and as the state supreme court has instructed us, that the focus should be on what influence the miscreant jurorâ€™s actions had upon the remaining jurors and whether her conduct prejudiced the outcome of the trial to such an extent that the parties did not receive a fair trial.Â  See State v. Grovenstein, 335 S.C. 347, 352, 517 S.E.2d 216, 218 (1999) (finding misconduct that does not affect the verdict does not entitle a party to a mistrial).Â  See also State v. Zeigler, 364 S.C. 94, 108, 610 S.E.2d 859, 866 (Ct. App. 2005) (stating â€œ[t]he general test for evaluating alleged juror misconduct is whether there in fact was misconduct and, if so, whether any harm resulted to the defendant as a consequence.â€).Â  
The errant jurorâ€™s activities were initially reported to the trial judge by an alternate juror, after the jury verdict was received.Â  That juror, being an alternate, was in no position to testify of her own knowledge as to what influence, if any, the misconduct had upon the other jurors during the deliberations that resulted in the verdict, as she would necessarily have been dismissed prior to the court submitting the case to the jury.Â  It is worth noting that none of the jurors who actually took part in the deliberations thought the misconduct egregious enough to report it to the court. 
The eminent trial court judge, following the procedure described by the state supreme court in State v. Aldret, 333 S.C. 307, 509 S.E.2d 811 (1999), held an extensive evidentiary hearing, assembling the jurors, minus the offending juror, and conducting voir dire to ascertain the nature and extent of the alleged misconduct and to determine if any of the misconduct affected the juryâ€™s impartiality so as to undermine the verdict.[15] 
Without reiterating the testimony of each individual juror and belaboring that issue, suffice it to say that the trial court made specific findings of fact to the effect that â€œ[a]ll of the jurors indicated that no improper conduct or outside influences tainted their unanimous verdict.â€Â  Continuing, the court stated it had â€œpreviously concluded in Order recorded on November 10, 2005 that Ms. Abrams (the miscreant juror) had violated the instructions of the Court by making improper comments to other jurors and she was sanctioned as a result of her actions.Â  However, the Court found at that time, and reaffirms by this Order, that the action of Ms. Abrams did not taint the judicial process or impact improperly on the juryâ€™s unanimous verdict.â€Â  
The remarks made by the trial court judge at the hearing resulting in the contempt citation to the offending juror are illustrative of his factual conclusions:

  The comments that were made in the jury room obviously were not heard by everybody.Â  And many of the jurors heard nothing at all.Â  And to their credit it appears that the jurors who did hear it did not respond to it in any way and did not act on it in their deliberations.Â  The jurors . . . unanimously said that they did not take those comments into account in their decision in this particular case.Â  
  . . .
  Iâ€™m convinced that they did not taint the process, but I have only been convinced by doing what we have done, that is to talk with each one of these jurors individually, to inquire about them, to take more of their time away from their jobs as well, to make sure that . . . the process has not been tainted by these improper discussions, deliberations, comments if you will, and actions on behalf of Mrs. Abrams.Â  

These findings of fact were made by an experienced trial court judge who was in a position not only to view the jurors as they testified, but also to have the additional benefit of personally conducting the examination, circumstances that allowed him to better evaluate their responses, both verbal and non-verbal, and thereby judge their credibility.Â  These are findings of fact that are entitled to great deference.Â  State v. Harris, 340 S.C. 59, 63, 530 S.E.2d 626, 628 (2000).Â  
I fear the majority opinion inadvertently injects into its analysis a â€œpresumption of prejudice,â€ thereby resurrecting a concept already specifically rejected.Â  See Grovenstein, 335 S.C. at 352, 517 S.E.2d at 218 (holding moving party has burden to demonstrate prejudice and adopting a â€œpresumption of prejudiceâ€ standard is erroneous).Â  
I would affirm.

[1]Â  We note the dissent quotes a different portion of the trial judgeâ€™s order in which the judge states, â€œAll of the jurors indicated that no improper conduct or outside influences tainted their unanimous verdict.â€Â  As the dissent points out, however, the trial court did not examine the offending juror so the trial judgeâ€™s reference to â€œallâ€ applies to the remaining jurors, not to all twelve.
[2]Â  Three jurors, however, indicated at one point in their examination by the trial judge that the offending jurorâ€™s comments had influenced them.Â  The first juror testified as follows:Â  

  
    Court:
    
     . . . Were you in any way influenced by the things that she said?
    
  
  
    Juror:    
    
    Yes.
    
  
  
    Court: 
    
    In what way?
    
  
  
    Juror:
    
    She just kept talking about church, you know, helping churches and . . .
    
  
  
    Court: 
    
    Right.
    
  
  
    Juror:
     
    And that she talked to her pastor and he was going to pray for us, but he knew that it was the right thing for us to do.
    
  
  
    Court:
    
    What was the right thing for you to do?
    
  
  
    Juror:  
    
    To just let the church get other churches to help.
    
  
  
    Court: 
      
    
    And were you convinced by what she said or by what her pastor said that that was the right thing to do?
      
    
    
  
  
    Juror:
    No, but I guess, you know, I couldn’t help but hear it, I heard it so much. 
  

Although perhaps not â€œconvincedâ€ (the trial judgeâ€™s word) by anything that the offending juror said, the first juror nonetheless admitted to being â€œinfluencedâ€ (again, the trial judgeâ€™s word) by those comments.Â  Improper influence, however slight, is still improper influence, or as Paul writes in Galatians 5:9 (RSV), â€œA little leaven leavens the whole lump.â€
Admittedly, the juror later backed off slightly on her admission of influence. When pressed by the trial judge about whether the offending jurorâ€™s comments â€œinfluenced [her] in making a decision,â€ she indicated they had done so; but then, when pressed further, she qualified her answer, saying that she was â€œstill not sureâ€ and â€œI donâ€™t think I based my decision on anything she said.â€Â  [Emphasis added.]Â  In other words, she could not tell the trial judge definitively whether the offending jurorâ€™s comments impacted her decision in the case or not.Â  Suffice it to say, the juror never testified that the comments and actions of the offending juror â€œhad no impactâ€ on her individual decision.
Like the first juror, the other two initially acknowledged the offending jurorâ€™s comments had indeed influenced them, at least somewhat.Â  One of these said, when asked whether what the offending juror said â€œha[d] any bearing on [the juror] making up [her] mind one way or the other,â€ replied, â€œA little.Â  She shouldnâ€™t have said nothing, you know, to the jury about it.â€Â  This juror later testified, however, that what the offending juror said did not cause her to decide the case â€œone way or another.â€Â  The other juror, when asked whether what the offending juror told her â€œha[d] any bearing on [her] decision,â€ answered, â€œWell, I canâ€™t say that it didnâ€™t, you know, come in my mind, you know. . . .Â  But I think â€“ I still made my decision based on the facts.â€ 
[3]Â  See Alston v. Black River Elec. Coop., 345 S.C. 323, 326, 548 S.E.2d 858, 859 (2001) (â€œUnder South Carolina law, litigants are guaranteed the right to an impartial jury.â€)
[4]Â  See State v. Kelly, 331 S.C. 132, 141, 502 S.E.2d 99, 104 (1998) (â€œUnless the misconduct affects the juryâ€™s impartiality, it is not such misconduct as will affect the verdict.â€)
[5]Â  66 C.J.S. New Trial Â§ 54, at 143 (1998).
[6] Â As Winston Churchill once observed, â€œThe scrutiny of 12 honest jurors provides defendant and plaintiff alike a safeguard from arbitrary perversion of the law . . . .â€ 2 J. Kendall Few, In Defense of Trial by Jury 395 (American Jury Trial Foundation 1993) (emphasis added).
[7]Â  66 C.J.S. New Trial Â§ 54, at 144.
[8]Â  See id. Â§ 58, at 147 (â€œAccording to some decisions a new trial must be granted if a juror joined in a discussion of the case; but according to others it must be shown that statements were made which might reasonably be presumed to have influenced the juror.â€ (footnote omitted)).
[9]Â  As early as in the second day of an extended trial, which lasted from August 8 through August 22, 2005, the offending juror reportedly told one of the other jurors:

  [T]he second day she said . . . we really donâ€™t have to go any further with this because the church should take care of the church. . . .Â  [S]he . . . [s]aid she talked to her preacher that night and he advised her . . . that churches need to stick together and help churches out. . . . . [S]he felt that way from day one.Â  

Another juror testified he recalled the offending juror â€œmaybe at the beginning saying that, you know, she kind of had her mind set [sic] up and again, when I started hearing different things about going, visiting the church.â€Â  
[10] State v. Aldret, 333 S.C. 307, 311, 509 S.E.2d 811, 813 (1999); State v. McGuire, 272 S.C. 547, 551, 253 S.E.2d 103, 105 (1979); cf. Proverbs 18:17 (RSV) (â€œHe who states his case first seems right, until the other comes and examines him.â€).
[11] 66 C.J.S. New Trial Â§ 61, at 149-50.
[12] See id., at 150 (stating the question of whether to grant a new trial for misconduct involving an improper site investigation by a juror depends on the circumstances of the particular case).
[13] See 75B Am. Jur. 2d Trial Â§ 1639, at 409 (1992) (stating a trial courtâ€™s determination regarding juror misconduct is reviewable for an abuse of discretion); see also Bishop v. Nicholson, 146 S.C. 245, 248, 143 S.E. 802, 803 (1928) (Blease, J., concurring) (indicating the standard of review in a juror misconduct case is an abuse of discretion standard); 66 C.J.S. New Trial Â§ 54, at 143 (â€œSeparate acts of misconduct may be sufficient, when combined, to require a new trial, although one of such acts alone would not be sufficient.â€).
[14] See Bishop, 146 S.C. at 247, 143 S.E. at 802 (affirming a trial judgeâ€™s grant of a new trial based on the disqualification of one juror where, after the trial, the plaintiff discovered one of the jurors had not disclosed he was employed at a mill where the defendant was president, even though the trial judge had specifically disqualified all persons employed by the mill from serving on the jury); id. at 248, 143 S.E. at 803 (concurring Justice Blease remarking, â€œ[T]he jury box must not only be kept pure, but . . . each individual juror ought to be above the least suspicion.â€ (emphasis added)). 
[15] In Aldret, the supreme court established a review process for juror misconduct that becomes apparent after the juryâ€™s verdict.Â  The court authorized the trial court to consider affidavits and conduct an evidentiary hearing.Â  333 S.C. at 315, 509 S.E.2d at 815.Â  Although this court found Aldret requires a hearing only where the misconduct is premature deliberation, this court did not conclude an Aldret hearing held for other types of misconduct would constitute error.Â  See Long v. Norris & Assocs., Ltd., 342 S.C. 561, 574, 538 S.E.2d 5, 12 (Ct. App. 2000).Â Â

title: Keane v. Lowcountry Pediatrics
description: In this legal and equitable action, Lowcountry Pediatrics, P.A., and Drs. Francis E. Rushton, Joseph H. Floyd, and Lawrence R. Coleman (collectively "Lowcountry"), appeal the trial court's order awarding damages to Drs. Timothy and Karen Keane.  Lowcountry contends the trial court erred in: (1) including goodwill in its valuation of Lowcountry; (2) awarding prejudgment interest; and (3) awarding punitive damages.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA


Â THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Timothy E. Keane and Karen L. Keane, Respondents,
v.
Lowcountry Pediatrics, P.A.; Beaufort Pediatrics, P.A.; Francis E.
Rushton, Jr.; Joseph H. Floyd; Lawrence R. Coleman, and Christine T. Chiaviello,
Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Beaufort County
Curtis L. Coltrane, Master-in-Equity and Special Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4199
Heard October 11, 2006 â€“ Filed January 29, 2007

REVERSED


  
    
      
James S. Gibson, Jr. and Mary B. Lohr, both of Beaufort, and William L. Howard, Sr., of Charleston, for Appellants.
Robert V. Mathison, Jr. of Hilton Head Island, for Respondents.
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.:Â  In this legal and equitable action, Lowcountry Pediatrics, P.A., and Drs. Francis E. Rushton, Joseph H. Floyd, and Lawrence R. Coleman (collectively â€œLowcountryâ€), appeal the trial courtâ€™s order awarding damages to Drs. Timothy and Karen Keane.Â  Lowcountry contends the trial court erred in: (1) including goodwill in its valuation of Lowcountry; (2) awarding prejudgment interest; and (3) awarding punitive damages.Â  We reverse.
FACTS
On September 1, 1986, Dr. Rushton and Dr. Floyd organized Lowcountry Pediatrics.Â  Rushton and Floyd later added Dr. Coleman to the practice, and the three became the senior physicians and shareholders of Lowcountry. Â Eventually, the Keanes and Dr. Christine Chiavello joined the practice, and all three became shareholders of Lowcountry.[1]Â  
Upon the admission of each new member into Lowcountry, the doctors amended the shareholder agreement to reflect the current value of a withdrawing shareholderâ€™s stock.Â  The shareholder agreement provided that upon a shareholderâ€™s withdrawal from the practice that shareholderâ€™s shares of stock would be bought back by Lowcountry at an agreed upon price. Â The shareholder agreement indicated the purchase price for the withdrawing shareholderâ€™s stock would remain in effect until a new value was agreed upon, in writing, following the end of each fiscal year.Â  Between 1989 and 1998, the doctors amended the shareholder agreement on three different occasions, and each amendment occurred after Lowcountry received an appraisal to calculate its fair market value.Â  The 1998 amendment was the final amendment prior to this controversy. Â Article 3.1 of the 1998 revision to the shareholder agreement stated:

Value of shares of stock:Â  For the purpose of this Third Amendment to Shareholders Agreement, the value of each share of issued stock . . . of the Agreement . . . is $15.30.Â  This value has been agreed upon by the shareholders as representing the fair value of each share of stock, including goodwill of the Association.

According to this amendment to the shareholder agreement, the Keanes owned a combined thirty percent of the shares in Lowcountry.[2] Â Â 
Some time after the third amendment to the shareholder agreement, the senior physicians began to contemplate the end of Lowcountry, complaining about the lack of physical space in the office as well as their differing views with the Keanes about the proper management of the practice.Â  As a result, on December 20, 1999, the senior physicians sent a letter to the Keanes notifying them of their desire to â€œsplit up Lowcountry Pediatrics.â€Â  The Keanes, however, had no desire to dissolve the practice, and despite the senior physiciansâ€™ repeated attempts to discuss dissolution, the Keanes declined to withdraw from the practice. 
Because no agreement could be reached to â€œsplit-upâ€ Lowcountry, the senior physicians called a shareholder meeting.Â  At the shareholder meeting, the doctors were to vote on, among other items, removing the non-complete agreement and obtaining an appraisal to value the shares of Lowcountry in order to effectuate the buy-out of the Keanes and Chiaviello.[3] Â At the meeting, the senior physicians voted in favor of removing the non-compete clause from the employment agreement.Â  The Keanes and the senior physicians disagreed on the appraisal.Â  The Keanes wanted the individual physiciansâ€™ goodwill included in the valuation of Lowcountry, but the senior physicians did not.Â  As a result of this disagreement, the senior physicians and Chiaviello voted to obtain an appraisal of Lowcountry by Webster, Rogers and Company with the Keanes abstaining from the vote. Â A â€œdraftâ€ appraisal was subsequently undertaken, and the appraisal indicated a value of $22.95 per share for the Lowcountry stock, excluding the individual physiciansâ€™ goodwill, with a total value of stockholdersâ€™ equity of $229,500. 
Based on this valuation, the senior physicians offered to purchase the Keanesâ€™ shares for $68,850.Â  Alternatively, the senior physicians gave notice of their intentions to withdraw from Lowcountry, offering to sell their shares to the Keanes for the same per share price.Â  The senior physicians provided the Keanes with sixty days to respond or Lowcountry would be dissolved pursuant to the shareholder agreement.Â  In June of 2000, the senior physicians increased their purchase offer to $100,000 for the Keanesâ€™ interest in Lowcountry.Â  The Keanes, however, continued to refuse to withdraw from the practice.Â  Lowcountry continued operating as a practice until July 24, 2000, sixty days after which the offer to buy or sell the senior physiciansâ€™ shares had expired.Â  
At this time, the senior physicians filed the articles of dissolution; changed the locks on the building; and opened their own practice, Beaufort Pediatrics, at the same location.[4]Â  All of the assets of Lowcountry, including the equipment, supplies, patient records, and bank accounts were utilized by Beaufort Pediatrics.Â  However, the accounts receivable of Lowcountry had been collected and distributed to the Keanes in proportion to their interest in Lowcountry.Â  The senior physicians also paid Lowcountry for the use of the fixed assets, rent, and supplies.Â  This money was also placed into the account for Lowcountry and distributed according to the interest of the shareholders, including the Keanes.
On September 22, 2000, the Keanes brought this action against Lowcountry alleging numerous causes of action, including a derivative action, a declaratory judgment action, and a claim pursuant to sections 33-14-310 and 320 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2000) to determine the fair market value of Lowcountry.Â  To this end, the Keanes obtained an appraisal of Lowcountry performed by Louis Fleishman.[5] Â Using the discounted future cash flow method, which included the individual physiciansâ€™ goodwill, Fleishman valued Lowcountry at $1,319,200. Â Fleishman valued the tangible assets at a total of $401,344, with $42,344 in fixed assets, $18,000 for supplies, and $341,000 for accounts receivable.Â  He valued the general intangibles, including the individual physiciansâ€™ goodwill, at $917,856. 
The master-in-equity: (1) determined the value of Lowcountry was $1,319,200; (2) found the Keanes were only entitled to thirty percent of the $917,856 intangible value of Lowcountry as they had already received their thirty percent interest in the tangible assets of Lowcountry; (3) awarded the Keanes $275,296 for their thirty percent interest in Lowcountry; (4) ordered prejudgment interest on the $275,296 award; (5) found the senior physicians had willfully and wantonly violated their fiduciary duties to the Keanes; and (6) awarded $50,000 in punitive damages to the Keanes.[6]Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
This appeal involves both equitable and legal causes of action.Â  When both equitable and legal causes of action are maintained in one suit, each must be analyzed separately according to its own identity as legal or equitable. Jordan v. Holt, 362 S.C. 201, 205, 608 S.E.2d 129, 131 (2005); Future Group, II v. Nationsbank, 324 S.C. 89, 97, 478 S.E.2d 45, 49 (1996). 
A corporate dissolution is an action in equity.Â  Jordan, 362 S.C. at 205, 608 S.E.2d at 131.Â  An action for shareholder oppression is also one in equity.Â  McDuffie v. Oâ€™Neal, 324 S.C. 297, 303, 476 S.E.2d 702, 705 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  In addition, an action to determine the fair market value of stocks owned by a dissenting shareholder constitutes a proceeding in equity to be tried by a judge without a jury.Â Â  Defender Props., Inc, v. Doby, 307 S.C. 336, 338, 415 S.E.2d 383, 384 (1992).Â  In an action in equity referred to a master, the appellate court may view the evidence to determine facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence, though it is not required to disregard the findings of the master.  Friarsgate, Inc. v. First Fed. Sav. & Loan Assâ€™n, 317 S.C. 452, 456, 454 S.E.2d 901, 904 (Ct. App. 1995).
The determination of the appropriateness of an award of pre-judgment interest, on the other hand, is a question of law because the right to relief is entirely statutory.Â  See, e.g.,Â  Harvey v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Corrections, 338 S.C. 500, 507, 527 S.E.2d 765, 769 (Ct. App. 2000) (finding â€œwhere the relief sought is entirely statutory . . . the action is one at law.â€).Â  Likewise, an action for punitive damages arising from a breach of fiduciary duty is a question of law.Â  Jordan, 362 S.C. at 205, 608 S.E.2d at 131.Â  â€œIn an action at law, on appeal of a case tried without a jury, the findings of fact of the judge will not disturbed upon appeal unless found to be without evidence which reasonably supports the judgeâ€™s findings.â€Â  Townes Assocs. v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 86, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775 (1976).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Calculation of Fair Market Value
Lowcountry argues the trial court erred in including the value of the physiciansâ€™ individual professional goodwill in the calculation of the fair market value of the association.Â  We agree.
While both parties correctly point out that no South Carolina authority specifically addresses the propriety of the inclusion of the physiciansâ€™ individual professional goodwill in the context of a dissolution of a professional association, we believe the cases of Donahue v. Donahue, 299 S.C. 353, 384 S.E.2d 741 (1989), and Weinberg v. Wallace, 314 S.C. 183, 442 S.E.2d 211 (Ct. App. 1994), are illustrative.
In Donahue, Wife sought an interest in Husbandâ€™s professional dental practice as part of the equitable distribution of the marital estate.Â  299 S.C. at 358, 384 S.E.2d at 744.Â  The family courtâ€™s valuation of the professional practice included Husbandâ€™s professional goodwill, and Husband appealed.Â  Id.Â  In considering Husbandâ€™s arguments, the supreme court reasoned that â€œthe very nature of a professional practice is that it is totally dependent upon the professional.â€Â  Id. at 360, 384 S.E.2d at 745.Â  Moreover, the supreme court recognized the speculative nature of professional goodwill because its valuation is based on the doctorâ€™s future earnings, which are totally dependent upon the professional.Â  Id. at 359, 384 S.E.2d at 745 (citing Casey v. Casey, 293 S.C. 503, 362 S.E.2d 6 (1987) (acknowledging the speculative nature of goodwill being dependent upon future earnings)).Â  The supreme court reasoned that professional goodwill:

[A]ttaches to the person of the professional man or woman as a result of confidence in his or her skill and ability.Â  It does not possess value or constitute an asset separate and apart from the professionalâ€™s person, or from his individual ability to practice his profession. Â It would be extinguished in the event of the professionalâ€™s death, retirement or disablement.

Id. at 359, 384 S.E.2d at 745 (citations omitted).Â  As a result, the supreme court held it was error to include professional goodwill in valuing Husbandâ€™s dental practice.Â  Id. at 360, 384 S.E.2d at 745.Â  
The view of professional goodwill attaching solely to the professional, not to the association, has been expanded outside of the family court arena.Â  In Weinberg v. Wallace, the court of appeals addressed whether Weinberg was allowed to recover for an alleged conversion of goodwill associated with a family business that was operated by Wallace.Â  314 S.C. at 185, 442 S.E.2d at 212.Â  The court of appeals, citing the Donahue analysis, reasoned:

If the business is a professional practice, then [goodwill] attaches solely to the person of the professional man or woman as a result of confidence in his or her skill and ability and does not possess value or constitute an asset separate and apart from the professionalâ€™s person.

Id. at 187, 442 S.E.2d at 213 (internal quotations omitted).Â  
The testimony of the Keanesâ€™ expert, Fleishman, echoes the decisions in Donahue and Weinberg regarding the speculative nature of valuing the physiciansâ€™ individual goodwill as well as its personal nature.Â  When Fleishman testified, he conceded that an element of the intangible value of Lowcountry is the â€œphysicians (sic) and their individual reputation.â€ Â Further, when asked hypothetically on cross-examination what the intangible value of a practice would be if three physicians were to quit the practice, Fleishman responded: â€œIf they truly go away, and no longer practice then a large portion of the intangible value would go away,â€ but that value would â€œbe hard to arrive at.â€Â  He continued: 

I would have to look and speculate and say what, what else is going to remain the same . . . Well, I donâ€™t think I could say, you know, put a specificâ€”well, that weâ€™ll take away half the intangibles or twenty percent or eight percent.Â  Thereâ€™s no specific formula attached to that.

Further, Fleishman testified the speculation required to determine the value remaining with the practice once a physician leaves is due to its intangible nature, and that determining what Lowcountry is worth is â€œnot entirely scientific.â€ 
The Donahue and Weinberg courts clearly held that South Carolina courts should not, in valuing a professional association, include the goodwill of the professional because of its speculative nature and the fact that goodwill â€œattaches solely to the person of the professional man or woman as a result of confidence in his or her skill and ability and does not possess value or constitute an asset separate and apart from the professionalâ€™s person.â€Â  See Donahue, 314 S.C. at 187, 442 S.E.2d at 213.Â  Fleishmanâ€™s own testimony only reinforces that holding.Â  As a result, the Keanes are not entitled to the $275,296 awarded by the master, which represented their thirty percent interest in the intangible value of Lowcountry.
We do not intend for this opinion to be interpreted as barring parties from contractually agreeing to include personal goodwill in the valuation of a shareholderâ€™s interest upon dissolution.Â  However, that theory was never advanced by the Keanes, either at trial or in their brief before this court, as the basis for their position.[7]Â  Accordingly, we do not believe it is appropriate to use it as an additional sustaining ground.Â  See Iâ€™on, L.L.C. v. Town of Mount Pleasant, 338 S.C. 406, 420, 526 S.E.2d 716 (2000) (holding, in the context of an appellate courtâ€™s authority to affirm for any reason appearing in the record, that â€œ[a] respondent may abandon an additional sustaining ground . . . by failing to raise it in an appellate brief.â€)Â  Moreover, even if we believed this argument was available as a basis for affirming, we do not agree that the language of the shareholder agreement controls this issue.Â  The agreement states that the value of $15.30 per share â€œhas been agreed upon by the shareholders as representing the fair value of each of stock, including goodwill of the Association.â€Â  We do not perceive the language â€œgoodwill of the Associationâ€ to be synonymous with the inclusion of individual physicianâ€™s goodwill upon a dissolution of the practice, and absent specific language that individual goodwill should be used to value a shareholderâ€™s interest upon dissolution, we believe this issue is controlled by Donahue and Weinberg.
Next, Lowcountry argues that should we find the trial court incorrectly included the physiciansâ€™ professional goodwill in the valuation of the Keanesâ€™ interest, we should use the value in its May 2000 appraisal to value the Keanesâ€™ interest.Â  We agree in part and disagree in part.
While we agree that the trial court erred in including the value of the goodwill of the individual physicians in the calculation of Lowcountryâ€™s fair market value, we disagree that the May 2000 appraisal is the appropriate gauge of Lowcountryâ€™s value.Â  Lowcountryâ€™s May 2000 appraisal was merely a â€œdraft,â€ and the appraiser who prepared it did not testify at trial.Â  Additionally, Lowcountry provided no other evidence of valuation of the corporate stock during the hearing.Â  Therefore, we believe the best evidence regarding the tangible value for Lowcountry remains the Keanesâ€™ appraisal prepared by Fleishman, less the amount attributed to the individual goodwill of the physicians.Â  Â Â Using the Keanesâ€™ own appraisal, we find, as did the trial court, that the fixed assets, supplies, and accounts receivable of Lowcountry were worth $401,344. 
In its amended order, the trial court found that â€œthe money from the accounts receivable, rent and supplies purchases were placed into the Lowcountry account and distributed in accordance with the respective percentages of ownership.â€ Â The trial court also found that the Keanes neither argued that the disbursements had been made, nor did the Keanes dispute that they had received their thirty percent of the tangible assets.Â  As a result, the trial court determined that the $401,344 of accounts receivable, rent, and supplies had already been distributed to, and received by, the Keanes according to their respective thirty percent interest in Lowcountry.[8]Â  Pursuant to our holding that the trial court incorrectly included the physiciansâ€™ individual professional goodwill in valuing the Keanesâ€™ interest in Lowcountry, the Keanes are only entitled to their thirty percent of the tangible assets of the association.Â  Because the Keanes have already received their entire thirty percent interest in the fair market value of Lowcountry, they are entitled to no additional distributions. Â Â 
II.Â  Award of Prejudgment Interest
Lowcountry Pediatrics next contends the trial court erred in awarding prejudgment interest to the Keanes.Â  We agree. 
Section 34-31-20 of the South Carolina Code (2005) provides that â€œin all cases of accounts stated and in all cases wherein any sum or sums of money shall be ascertained and, being due, shall draw interest according to law, the legal interest shall be at the rate of eight and three-fourths percent per annum.â€ Â Such prejudgment interest, however, is allowed on an obligation to pay money â€œfrom the time when, either by agreement of the parties or operation of the law, the payment is demandable, if the sum is certain or capable of being reduced to certainty.â€Â  Babb v. Rothrock, 310 S.C. 350, 353, 426 S.E.2d 789, 791 (1993).Â  In other words, an award of prejudgment interest is not proper if the measure of recovery is not fixed by conditions existing at the time the claim arose.Â  Id.
In this matter, the trial court awarded $275,296 in actual damages to the Keanes pursuant to their claim for breach of fiduciary duty.Â  At oral argument, however, the Keanesâ€™ attorney conceded these actual damages were based solely on the valuation of Lowcountryâ€™s stock, which is an equitable cause of action.Â  In other words, the trial court found the damages under the legal and equitable causes of action to be one in the same.Â  This award equaled the Keanesâ€™ thirty percent interest in the practice based on the Fleishman appraisal, which included goodwill.Â  Pursuant to our holding that the trial court incorrectly included the physiciansâ€™ individual professional goodwill in valuing the Keanesâ€™ interest in Lowcountry, we find the Keanes are not entitled to the $275,296 awarded to them by the trial court.Â  Therefore, no award of actual damages exists upon which prejudgment interest can be awarded.[9] Â Â 
III.Â  Punitive Damages
Lowcountry Pediatrics contends the trial court erred in ordering punitive damages to the Keanes on their claim for breach of fiduciary duty.Â  We agree.
â€œPunitive damages can only be awarded where the plaintiff proves by clear and convincing evidence the defendantâ€™s misconduct was willful, wanton, or in reckless disregard of the plaintiffâ€™s rights.â€Â 
Austin v. Specialty Transp. Serv., 358 S.C. 298, 313, 594 S.E.2d 867, 875 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  Punitive damages, however, may only be awarded upon an underlying finding of actual damages.Â  Dowling v. Home Buyers Warranty Corp., 311 S.C. 233, 236, 428 S.E.2d 709, 711 (1993).Â  
In this matter, the trial court awarded $275,296 in actual damages to the Keanes pursuant to their claim for breach of fiduciary duty.Â  This award equaled the Keanesâ€™ thirty percent interest in the goodwill amount as included in the Fleishman appraisal.Â  As mentioned previously, the Keanesâ€™ attorney conceded during oral argument these actual damages were tied solely to the equitable valuation of Lowcountryâ€™s stock.Â  Pursuant to our holding that the trial court incorrectly included the physiciansâ€™ individual professional goodwill in valuing the Keanesâ€™ interest in Lowcountryâ€™s stock, we have removed the underlying award of actual damages on which the circuit court based the award of punitive damages.Â  Therefore, the award of punitive damages cannot prevail without a finding of actual damages, and accordingly, the award of punitive damages is reversed.[10]Â  See Dowling, 311 S.C. at 236, 428 S.E.2d at 711 (holding punitive damages may only be awarded upon an underlying finding of actual damages).Â  
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, the order of the circuit court is hereby 
 REVERSED.[11]
STILWELL, J., concurs.
KITTREDGE, J., dissents in a separate opinion. 
KITTREDGE, J., dissenting in part and concurring in part:Â Â Â Â Â Â  
I dissent in part and concur in part.Â  I respectfully dissent from the reversal of the masterâ€™s award of actual and punitive damages to the Keanes.Â  I agree with the majority opinion that the masterâ€™s award of prejudgment interest to the Keanes should be reversed.
The first issue to address is our standard of review.Â  Although the Keanes prevailed on multiple theories (legal and equitable), the majority focuses exclusively on the equitable corporate dissolution claim.Â  By excluding consideration of the legal claim, the court easily segues to an equitable standard of review and determines its own view of the facts.Â  The result is a factual recitation in a light most favorable to Appellants.Â  I would not ignore the legal claim and the more deferential scope of review that flows from it.Â  
The master found that Appellants breached their fiduciary duty to the Keanes.Â  This finding has not been appealed and is the law of this case.Â  See Dreher v. Dreher, 370 S.C. 75, __ n.1, 634 S.E.2d 646, 647 n.1(2006) (â€œ[A]n unappealed ruling becomes the law of the case and precludes further consideration of the issue on appeal[.]â€) (citing In re Morrison, 321 S.C. 370, 372 n.2, 468 S.E.2d 651, 652 n.2 (1996)).Â  A fair reading of the masterâ€™s order indicates the award of actual damages (for all causes of action) represented his judgment of the value of the Keanesâ€™s interest in Lowcountry Pediatrics.Â  The majority so acknowledges in observing that â€œthe trial court awarded $275,296 in actual damages to the Keanes pursuant to their claim for breach of fiduciary duty.â€Â Â  
An action for breach of fiduciary duty is an action at law.Â  As such, we are constrained to uphold the masterâ€™s findings if supported by any evidence. See Jordan v. Holt, 362 S.C. 201, 205, 608 S.E.2d 129, 131 (2005) (â€œ[A] claim of breach of fiduciary duty is an action at law and the trial judgeâ€™s findings will be upheld unless without evidentiary support.â€).Â  The master, who was in a better position to assess witness credibility and demeanor, viewed the evidence in a light less favorable to Appellants.Â  I would hold there is evidence in the record to support the masterâ€™s findings.
There is another reason I would not focus the analysis on corporate dissolution law.Â  There was no corporate dissolution (or â€œwinding upâ€) of the medical practice.Â  Articles of dissolution were prepared and Appellants represented to the Keanes that the medical practice would be dissolved; the articles of dissolution, however, were not filed with the South Carolina Secretary of Stateâ€™s office.Â Â Â  More to the point, Appellants conceded at trial that there was no dissolution[12] and that Lowcountry Pediatrics should be â€œconsidered a going concern.â€[13]Â  After Appellantsâ€™ initial efforts to force the Keanes from the medical practice failed (using the ploy of dissolution and otherwise), Appellants changed the locks to the office while the Keanes were on vacation.Â  The medical practice continued without missing a beat, as Appellants simply replaced the sign for â€œLowcountry Pediatricsâ€ with â€œBeaufort Pediatricsâ€ and carried on using Lowcountryâ€™s office equipment and phone number.Â  
I would honor Appellantsâ€™ trial stipulation to value the medical practice as a going concern.Â  I would not, as the majority does, value â€œgoodwill in the context of a dissolution of a professional association.â€Â  There was no dissolution.
I now turn to the majorityâ€™s rejection of goodwill as a component of the value of the medical practice.Â  As pointed out by the majority, Article 3.1 of the April 22, 1998 amendments to the shareholder agreement made no change in the requirement to include the goodwill of Lowcountry Pediatrics in determining â€œthe fair value of each share of stock.â€Â  In my view, South Carolina law does not forbid parties from contracting to include goodwill as a component of value.[14]Â  I see nothing in the Donahue v. Donahue[15] line of cases precluding consideration of goodwill when the parties so contract.Â  Donahue and other cases cited by the majority do not address the issue before us: whether parties may contractually bind themselves to include goodwill in the value of a professional association.Â  It may be difficult to place a value on goodwill, but contracting to include goodwill is neither illegal nor contrary to public policy. 
Because the shareholder agreement provides a basis for including goodwill in the value of the medical practice, it may appear that the master should have similarly embraced the $15.30 price per share of stock as set forth in the April 1998 amended shareholder agreement.Â  There are two fundamental reasons why the master did not value the stock at $15.30 per share.Â  First, Appellants have never relied on this figure, neither in the trial court nor this court.Â  Second, when the partiesâ€™ dispute came to a head in early 2000, Appellants commissioned a new appraisal of the practiceâ€”Appellants did not rely on the April 1998 assigned value of $15.30 per share.Â  The result was a â€œdraftâ€ appraisal of $229,500 for the medical practice, or $22.95 per share.Â  Appellants concede this â€œdraftâ€ appraisal â€œdid not include good will [sic].â€Â  (Appellantsâ€™ final brief, 11).Â  Finally, beyond Appellantsâ€™ â€œdraftâ€ appraisal, as the majority points out, Appellants â€œprovided no other evidence of valuation of the corporate stock during the hearing.â€Â  
The holding of the majority rests on the principle that â€œindividual professional goodwillâ€ is not a proper component of the value â€œin the context of a dissolutionâ€ of a professional practice.Â  I do not necessarily oppose this principle.Â  To reach this conclusion, however, we must ignore basic rules of issue preservation.Â  See Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (holding an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review).Â  I have already noted that Appellants conceded at trial there was no dissolution and that the medical practice should be valued as a going concern.[16]Â  The result the court reaches today (while ostensibly sound in the abstract) rests on issues and arguments that were never presented in the trial.Â  We end up with a different case than the one tried before the master.Â  I would honor our basic issue preservation rules and not permit Appellants to try a different case than was presented in the trial court.Â  I would not punish the Keanesâ€”the Respondentsâ€”for failing to rebut in the trial court issues that were conceded and arguments that were never made at trial.[17]Â  
The majority further finds that the Keanes never advanced the theory that they were entitled to goodwill because of its inclusion in the shareholder agreement â€œeither at trial or in their brief before this court.â€ Â This is not so.Â  The Keanes did, in fact, rely on the agreementâ€™s inclusion of goodwill at trial and in brief to this court.Â  For example, Dr. Timothy Keane testified about the shareholder agreement and answered affirmatively when asked if the agreement included â€œan allocation of Good Will [sic].â€Â  The record contains many references to the shareholder agreement and goodwill.Â  In their brief to this court, the Keanes again relied on the language of the agreement, noting it â€œexpressly included good will [sic].â€Â  (Respondentsâ€™ final brief, 7).Â  If it appears the agreementâ€™s inclusion of goodwill was not a focus at trial, it should not inure to Appellantsâ€™ benefit on general issue preservation principles. 
The bottom line is that in valuing the Keanesâ€™s interest in Lowcountry Pediatrics as a going concern and assessing damages, under the â€œany evidenceâ€ standard of review, there is evidence supporting the masterâ€™s inclusion of goodwill in the value of the medical practice.Â  Because there is some evidence to support the masterâ€™s determination of value and award of actual damages, I would affirm the award.Â  
I would also affirm the masterâ€™s award of punitive damages to the Keanes.Â  My analysis begins with this courtâ€™s standard of review.Â  We should affirm if there is any evidence in the record to support the masterâ€™s finding that Appellantsâ€™ misconduct was willful, wanton, or in reckless disregard of the Keanesâ€™s rights.Â  See Jordan, 362 S.C. at 207, 608 S.E.2d at 132 (â€œ[Appellate courts] must affirm the trial courtâ€™s finding of punitive damages if any evidence reasonably supports the judgeâ€™s factual findings.â€).Â  I would find there is evidence in the record to support the masterâ€™s finding.Â  
Finally, I concur with the majority in result that the masterâ€™s award of prejudgment interest to the Keanes should be reversed.Â  â€œThe proper test for determining whether prejudgment interest may be awarded is whether the measure of recovery, not necessarily the amount of damages, is fixed by conditions existing at the time the claim arose.â€Â 
Butler Contracting, Inc. v. Court Street, LLC, 369 S.C. 121, __, 631 S.E.2d 252, 259 (2006).Â  An award of prejudgment interest in this case would be improper because the measure of recovery was â€œnot fixed by conditions existing at the time the claim arose.â€Â  While the parties understood goodwill was to be included in the value, the varying approaches to goodwill valuation is at odds with the idea of a liquidated claim and a fixed measure of recovery. 

[1]  The Keanes, along with the other doctors, signed employment contracts.Â  These contracts provided for a one-year term of employment and contained a non-compete clause.Â  
[2]  The Keanes collectively owned 3,000 of the 10,000 shares of Lowcountry.
[3]  Chiaviello voluntarily resigned from the practice at this time.Â  Chiavielloâ€™s resignation was accepted at the shareholders meeting.
[4]  The Secretary of State eventually returned the articles of dissolution to Lowcountry.Â  
[5]  Fleishman previously prepared an appraisal valuing Lowcountry in 1995, utilizing the â€œdiscounted cash flow method,â€ which included goodwill.
[6] Â Â Â Â Â Â  After receiving post-trial motions, the master issued an amended order correcting some computational errors but provided no substantive changes. 
[7]  Moreover, if the Keanes believed the terms of the shareholder agreement controlled, they should have been eager to accept the $68,850â€”not to mention the $100,000â€”offered by the senior physicians for their thirty percent interest in Lowcountry, as that offer exceeded by $22,950 the $45,900 the Keanes would have been entitled to under the shareholder agreement.
[8]  The Keanes do not appeal from this finding of the trial court.Â  It is, therefore, the law of the case.Â  See Charleston Lumber Co. v. Miller Housing Corp., 338 S.C. 171, 175, 525 S.E.2d 869, 871 (2000) (holding an unappealed ruling, right or wrong, is the law of the case.).
[9]  In so holding we do not disregard our standard of review for the breach of fiduciary duty cause of action, which is a legal claim.Â  Rather, we merely hold there are no damages to be awarded under the breach of fiduciary duty cause of action pursuant to our holding that the trial court incorrectly included the physiciansâ€™ individual professional goodwill in valuing the Keanesâ€™ interest in Lowcountryâ€™s stock.Â  The Keanesâ€™ concession at oral argument supports this view.Â  Â Â 
[10] 
The Keanesâ€™ reliance on Cook v. Atlantic Coast Line R. Co., 183 S.C. 279, 190 S.E. 923 (1934) is misplaced.Â  The Keanes rely on Cook for the proposition that an award of punitive damages may be allowed to stand despite no finding of actual damages.Â  That is not the import of Cook, however.Â  The holding in Cook is that an award for punitive damages may be allowed to stand if â€œit is clearly shown that legal right has been willfully or recklessly invaded and that nominal actual damages were merged in the verdict for punitive damages.â€Â  Id. at ___, 190 S.E. at 924 (emphasis added).Â  Here, we have removed the award of punitive damages in its entirety, and accordingly, there is no award of actual damages to merge with the award of punitive damages.Â  Therefore, Cook is inapplicable because that case requires, at a minimum, an award of nominal actual damages before an award of punitive damages may be upheld.
[11] 
In light of our disposition of this case, we need not address the Keanesâ€™ remaining issue regarding the two-issue rule.Â  See 
Whiteside v. Cherokee County Sch. Dist. No. One, 311 S.C. 335, 340, 428 S.E.2d 886, 889 (1993) (stating appellate court need not address remaining issues when resolution of prior issue is dispositive).
[12] 
I would not permit Appellants to resurrect in this court an argument abandoned at trial.
[13] 
Appellants had the medical practice appraised as a going concern in 1995 when Beaufort Memorial Hospital was considering purchasing Lowcountry Pediatrics.Â  That value, obtained by and for Appellants, included goodwill and was â€œapproximately $145,300 to $860,000.â€Â  
[14] 
Perhaps the shareholder agreement, by its terms, may be applied only in the case of a â€œwithdrawingâ€ shareholder, but such an argument was never made by Appellants.
[15] 
299 S.C. 353, 384 S.E.2d 741 (1989).
[16] 
Appellate counsel did not represent Appellants at trial.
[17] 
While this court â€œmay affirm any ruling, order, or judgment upon any ground(s) appearing in the Record on Appeal,â€ Rule 220(c), SCACR, I know of no basis to reverse the trial court when the ground does not appear in the record.
